title: Linda Mc Company v. Shore
description: In this opinion, the Court of Appeals affirms the circuit court's issuance of an order to execute and levy a judgment against appellants.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The Linda Mc
          Company, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        James G. Shore and Jan Shore, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
William T. Moody, Special Referee
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4279
Heard June 5, 2007 â€“ Filed July 26, 2007
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled
November 2, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John Martin Foster, of Rock Hill, for
          Appellants.
        James R. Snell, Jr., of Lexington, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: James and Jan Shore (the Shores) appeal the issuance of an order
  to execute and levy a judgment against them.Â  The Shores contend the judgment
  was void, the judgment lacked active energy because it was more than ten years
  old, there was an accord and satisfaction of the debt, and the Linda Mc Company
  (the Company) should be estopped from denying the accord and satisfaction.Â  We
  affirm.
I.
On December 8, 1994, the Shores agreed to
  give the Company a judgment by confession (the Judgment) as settlement of
  litigation over unpaid sales commissions.Â  The Judgment was entered on June 2,
  1995, and provided in relevant part as follows:

  1.Â  [The Shores] confess judgment to [the Company] in the amount
    of $110,000.00 and hereby authorize the Clerk of Court for Lancaster County,
    South Carolina, to enter judgment in favor of [the Company] against [the
    Shores], jointly and severally, for such amount, plus such costs and reasonable
    attorneysâ€™ fees incurred by [the Company] in enforcing the unconditional
    guaranty, a copy of which is attached hereto as Exhibit 1 (the â€œGuarantyâ€). . .
    .
  2.Â  [The Shores] agree that [the Company] may immediately, by
    affidavit through its attorneys, set forth the correct amount of this Judgment
    by adjusting the amount stated above for any credits previously applied by [the
    Company], and that [the Company] may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction
    for a judgment against [the Shores], jointly and severally, in the amount of
    the total sum due and owing hereunder, plus costs and reasonable attorneysâ€™
    fees incurred by [the Company] in enforcing the Guaranty, without further
    notice to [the Shores] and without further authority from [the Shores];
    provided, however, that in no event may said sum exceed $110,000.00, plus costs
    and reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees incurred by [the Company] in enforcing the
    Guaranty.Â  [The Shores] authorize the entry of judgment for the amount due and
    owing as set out in the affidavit, which judgment will continue to bear
    interest at the highest legal rate permitted by law.Â  The Judgment by
    Confession is not contingent upon any other considerations or proceedings and
    the Court is authorized to enter judgment for the amount set forth in the
    affidavit.

Sometime
  after the Judgment was entered, the Shores paid the Company $55,000.Â  On
  February 20, 2004, the Company wrote a letter (the Agreement) to the Shores
  wherein it agreed to waive all post-judgment interest if the Company received
  the remaining $55,000 before May 7, 2004.Â  The Shores paid the Company $26,750
  by check dated May 13, 2004.Â  Â Â 
The sheriff sought to execute on the
  Judgment, but as is customary, the execution was returned nulla bona.[1]Â  On July 29, 2004, the Company filed
  a petition for supplemental proceedings.Â  The Company countered that the Shores
  possessed assets subject to execution on the Judgment.Â  On August 3, 2004, the
  Shores issued a check to the Company in the amount of $28,500.Â  The
  trial court granted the Companyâ€™s petition for supplemental proceedings on
  August 9, 2004, and referred the matter to a special referee.Â  
On October 1, 2004, the referee conducted
  a hearing to determine whether the Shores had any assets that could be used to
  satisfy the remaining balance on the Judgment.Â  Prior to the hearing, the Shores
  filed a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP, asserting in part that
  the Judgment was void for lack of an affidavit.Â  The motion was denied on December 1, 2004, as the referee
  concluded the Judgment was valid and enforceable.Â  
On May 24, 2005, the referee conducted an additional hearing at
  which the Shores asserted the Agreement had been modified by a phone message
  Jan left at the Companyâ€™s attorneyâ€™s office.Â  This phone message, according to
  the Shores, constituted an accord and satisfaction of the debt.Â  In particular, Jan testified that in May
  2004 she left the Companyâ€™s attorney two messages explaining the Shores were
  sending half of the amount due and â€œif there was any problem with thatâ€ to call
  her and she would â€œget the other half put together.â€Â  In the message,
  she also stated she would pay the outstanding amount at the end of the next
  quarter, meaning July or August.Â  Additionally, the Shores introduced their
  phone records showing a call lasting two minutes was placed to the Companyâ€™s attorney
  on May 13, 2004.Â  The Companyâ€™s attorney testified that although his
  secretary checked and logged his messages, she would often not include the
  content of the messages.Â  He recalled receiving a couple of phone calls
  from the Shores but did not know what they were about and never called the
  Shores back.Â  
The
  Judgment was subject to execution and levy until June 2, 2005.Â  On June 3,
  2005, the referee issued his report to the circuit court finding there had been
  no accord and satisfaction.Â  The referee also found the Shores owed interest
  outstanding from the entry of the Judgment to date, as well as costs and
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  On the same day, June 3, the circuit court issued an
  order to execute and levy.Â  The Shores did not raise the matter of the Judgmentâ€™s
  expiration in the trial court.Â  On June 24, 2005, three weeks after the
  Judgment expired, the Shores filed a notice of appeal.Â  
II.
A.Â  Validity of the
  Judgment 
The
  Shores argue that because the Company failed to follow the terms of paragraph 2
  in the Judgment to fix the amount of Judgment by affidavit, its filing was void
  and the court was without jurisdiction. Â We
  disagree.
The Judgment complies with the statutory requirements
  of section 15-35-360 of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  This section provides:

  Before a judgment by confession shall be entered a
    statement in writing must be made and signed by the defendant and verified by
    his oath to the following effect: (1) It must state the amount for
    which judgment may be entered and authorize the entry of judgment therefor; (2) If it be for the money due
    or to become due, it must state concisely the facts out of which it arose and
    must show that the sum confessed therefor is justly due or to become due; and (3) If it be for the purpose of
    securing the plaintiff against a contingent liability, it must state concisely
    the facts constituting the liability and must show that the
    sum confessed therefor does not exceed the liability.

The Judgment sets forth that the Shores owe â€œ$110,000, plus costs
  and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by Plaintiff in enforcing the
  Guaranty.â€Â  The Judgment was made in writing and signed by the Shores and
  verified by their oath.Â  Post-judgment interest accrued as a matter of law.Â  The
  Judgment satisfies the statutory requirements.
The
  Shoresâ€™ argument centers on the fact that the Company never filed the affidavit
  setting forth the amount of Judgment specified in paragraph 2 of the Judgment.Â 
  The language pertaining to the affidavit, however, is permissive and not
  mandatory; it states an affidavit may be filed.Â  Further, the failure to
  file the affidavit does not render the Judgment void as contemplated by Rule
  60(b)(4), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b)(4) provides the court may relieve a party or his legal
  representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding if the judgment is
  void.Â  â€œThe definition of â€˜voidâ€™ under the rule
  only encompasses judgments from courts which failed to provide proper due
  process, or judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction or
  personal jurisdiction.â€Â  McDaniel v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co.,324 S.C. 639,
  644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  The absence of an affidavit has no bearing on the subject matter
  jurisdiction of the court.Â  The referee properly concluded that the Judgment
  was not void. 
B.Â  Filing of Judgment
  Within Ten Years
The
  Shores argue because the ten-year period expired on June 2, 2005, section
  15-39-30 deprives the Judgment of active energy, thereby rendering the June 3,
  2005 order ineffective.Â  This argument was not presented to the trial court,
  and we find the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional
  circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).
Application
  of issue preservation principles may appear harsh under these circumstances,
  for the Shoresâ€™ ability to challenge the ten-year limitation period did not
  arise until the statutory period ran on June 2, 2005.Â  Yet the Shores had the
  opportunity to raise the defense in a motion to amend their pleadings or a
  motion to alter, amend or vacate and did not do so.Â  
We
  believe this courtâ€™s opinion in LaRosa v. Johnston, 328 S.C. 293, 493
  S.E.2d 100 (Ct. App. 1997), requires us to dispose of this challenge on issue
  preservation principles.[2]Â  In LaRosa, the
  judgment was entered on March 11, 1986.Â  328 S.C. at 295, 493 S.E.2d at 101.Â 
  Supplemental proceedings were instituted prior to the expiration of the
  ten-year period set forth in section 15-39-30;
  however, the trial court signed an order in connection with collection of the
  judgment on March 15, 1996.Â  Id. at 296, 493 S.E.2d at 101.Â  The clerk
  filed the order on March 18, 1996.Â  Id.Â  As we observed, â€œStarting on
  March 11, 1986, the judgment was good until March 11, 1996.â€Â  328 S.C. at 297,
  493 S.E.2d at 102.Â  Following the March 18, 1996 order, Johnston moved to
  â€œalter, amend, and vacate [the trial courtâ€™s order], because LaRosaâ€™s judgment
  against Johnston expired on March 11, 1996â€”ten years after the judgment was
  filed.â€Â  Id. at 296, 493 S.E.2d at 101.Â  The trial court denied the
  motion and we reversed, holding the judgment expired on March 11, 1996.Â  Id. at 300, 493 S.E.2d at 103.
It
  appears that LaRosa objected to the court considering a defense not included in
  the pleadings.Â  We rejected LaRosaâ€™s argument: â€œWhen the judgment expired, Johnston acquired a statutory defense that had previously been unavailable.Â  We are not going
  to penalize Johnston for failing to raise a defense which she could not have
  raised.â€Â  Id. at 297, 493 S.E.2d at 102.Â  The point is that Johnston did assert the statutory defense as soon as it became available by way of
  a motion to alter.Â  Because the statutory defense was brought to the trial
  courtâ€™s attention as soon as the defense became available, the trial court
  addressed the very issue that was subsequently challenged on appeal.
At
  oral argument, the Shores took the position that the expiration of ten-year
  time limit on judgments impacts subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Thus, according
  to the Shores, this issue may be raised at any timeâ€”even for the first time on
  appeal.Â  The Shores do not, however, cite authority for this argument.Â  We can
  find no South Carolina case law to support the Shoresâ€™ argument that this is an
  issue of subject matter jurisdiction, and this court in LaRosa and A
    Fast Photo Express certainly did not treat the ten-year time limit on
  judgments in section 15-39-30 as jurisdictional.
We
  find further support for our holding today in a recent decision from our
  supreme court.Â  In Lever v. Lighting Galleries, Inc., 374 S.C. 30, 31,
  647 S.E.2d 214, 215 (2007), Lever borrowed money from Lighting Galleries in
  1988.Â  The debt was secured by a Note, together with a mortgage on property
  Lever owned in Aiken County.Â  Id.Â  When Lever failed to pay Lighting
  Galleries in accordance with the partiesâ€™ agreement, Lighting Galleries brought
  suit on the note and obtained a judgment in April 1989.Â  Id.Â  â€œLighting
  Galleries was unable to collect on its judgment, which expired ten years later,
  in April 1999.â€Â  Id. at 32, 647 S.E.2d at 215.Â  After the judgment
  lienâ€™s expiration, Lever brought an action arguing that the expired judgment on
  the note barred a foreclosure action.Â  Id. at 32, 647 S.E.2d at 215-16.Â 
  The court rejected Leverâ€™s argument: â€œWe hold that Lighting Galleries
  may pursue a foreclosure action notwithstanding its judgment against Lever was
  extinguished by virtue of the statute of limitations.â€Â  Id. at 36, 647
  S.E.2d at 218.Â  Thus, our supreme court construes the ten-year time limit on
  judgments in section 15-39-30 as a statute of limitations.Â  
This
  appears to be the prevailing law across the country, for in our research, we
  have found that other jurisdictions treat enactments similar to section
  15-39-30 as statutes of limitations on judgments.Â  See 47 Am. Jur. 2d. Judgments Â§ 781 (2006) (â€œA judgment creditor generally has the right to bring an action
  on the judgment at any time after its rendition, until barred by an applicable
  statute of limitations.â€); see also, e.g., Elliott v.
    Estate of Elliott, 596 S.E.2d 819, 821 (N.C. Ct. App. 2004) (â€œNorth
  Carolina imposes a ten-year statute of limitations upon the enforcement of a
  judgment or decree of any court of the United States.â€); Allied Funding v. Huemmer, 626
  A.2d 1055, 1060-61 (Md. Ct. Spec. App. 1993) (holding
  the twelve-year â€œstatute of limitationsâ€ began to run when the confessed
  judgment was entered and barred a subsequent suit); Cottrill v. Cottrill, 631
  S.E.2d 609, 612-13 (W. Va. 2006) (noting
  a statutory requirement to execute a judgment within a ten-year period is a
  â€œstatute of limitationsâ€ and, therefore, an affirmative defense).Â  Because
  section 15-39-30 operates as a statute of limitations, it constitutes a matter
  of avoidance under Rule 8(c), SCRCP, and must be raised in the trial court when
  the defense becomes available.Â  
In
  the case before us, the Shores never raised this statutory defense to the trial
  court by way of a motion to alter, amend, vacate or otherwise.Â 
  Consequently, we conclude the Shoresâ€™ newly asserted defense under section
  15-39-30 is not preserved for appellate review.Â  We understand that our ruling
  allows the underlying judgment to have active energy beyond the ten-year
  statutory period, but our rejection of the Shoresâ€™ subject matter jurisdiction
  argument and the concomitant application of issue preservation principles
  compels the result we reach today.Â  
C.Â  Accord and
  Satisfaction
The
  Shores maintain because the Company was aware of the Shoreâ€™s proposal to modify
  the Agreement, the referee erred in finding there was no accord and
  satisfaction.Â Â  We disagree.
An accord and satisfaction occurs when there is: (1)
  an agreement to accept in discharge of an obligation something different from
  that which the creditor is claiming or is entitled to receive; and (2) payment
  of the consideration expressed in the new agreement. Tremont Constr. Co. v.
    Dunlap, 310
  S.C. 180, 182, 425 S.E.2d 792, 793 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Like any contract, an accord
  and satisfaction requires a meeting of the minds.Â  Keels v. Pierce, 315 S.C. 339, 343, 433
  S.E.2d 902, 905 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  The debtor must intend and make unmistakably clear the
  payment tendered fully satisfies the creditorâ€™s demand and the creditor must
  accept payment with the intention that it will operate as a satisfaction.Â  Tremont Constr. Co., 310 S.C. at 182, 425
  S.E.2d at 793.Â  Without an agreement to discharge the obligation there can be no
  accord, and without an accord there can be no satisfaction.Â  Id.
The
  Shores contend the Agreement and subsequent cashing of the late check created
  an accord and satisfaction of the debt.Â  They further maintain the phone
  messages left by Jan modified the Agreement to allow for the remaining payment
  to be late.Â  The referee found there was no meeting of the minds.Â  The referee
  further found the Shores did not comply with the terms of the Agreement because
  the Shores made the outstanding $55,000.00 payment after the date called for in
  the Agreement.Â  As a result, the referee found there was no accord and
  satisfaction.Â  We find no error by the referee in this regard. 
D.Â  Estoppel
The
  Shores argue the Company had a duty to respond to the Shoresâ€™ proposal to
  modify the Agreement and failing that duty the Company is estopped from denying
  the modification of the Agreement.Â  This argument was neither presented to nor
  addressed by the trial court.Â  Consequently, it is not preserved for review on
  appeal.Â  In re Michael H., 360 S.C. at
  546, 602 S.E.2d at 732; Lucas, 359 S.C. at 510-11, 598 S.E.2d at 715.Â  
III.
For
  the reasons stated above, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 



[1] Â Nulla bona is â€œa form of return by a sheriff
  or constable upon an execution when the judgment debtor has no seizable
  property within the jurisdiction.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1095 (7th ed.
  1999).
[2] Â A Fast Photo
  Express, Inc. v. First National Bank of Chicago, 369 S.C. 80, 630 S.E.2d 285 (Ct. App. 2006), further
  buttresses our decision.Â  In A Fast Photo Express, the judgment
  against the appellants expired on September 30, 2004.Â  369 S.C. at 86, 630
  S.E.2d at 288.Â  An order, however, was issued by the master on September 23,
  2004.Â  Id.Â  Appellants filed their notice of appeal prior to the
  expiration of the judgment on September 27, 2004.Â  Id.Â  This court did
  not reach the merits, and held that because â€œthe issue of whether the judgment
  had expired was never raised to the master prior to the filing of the [appellantâ€™s]
  appeal,â€ and the appellants raised the issue for the first time on appeal, the
  matter was not preserved.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

title: Brazell v. Windsor
description: The contract breach involved in this case was determined not to be fundamental and substantial enough to defeat the purpose of the contract, and the appellants are not entitled to the remedy of rescission.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Cecil Brazell
      and Jackie Brazell, Appellants,
				v.
				Audrey B.
      Windsor, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4309
Heard October 11, 2007 â€“Filed November 8,
  2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brian Dumas, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				J. Rutledge Young, Jr., Stephen L. Brown, and William Howard, Sr.,
  all of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.:Â  Cecil and Jackie Brazell appeal the order of the circuit court
  dismissing their request for the remedy of rescission.Â  The order was issued
  following a motion made pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) of the South Carolina Rules
  of Civil Procedure.Â  We affirm.[1] 
 
FACTS
On October 20, 2004, the Brazells
  and Audrey Windsor entered into a contract for the purchase and sale of a home
  located at 8509 Oyster Factory Road, Edisto Island, South Carolina.Â  The
  parties agreed that the closing date would be November 30, 2004.Â  The Brazells had
  executed a HUD-1 Settlement Statement and deed conveying the property to Windsor in advance of the closing date.Â  The total purchase price was $550,000, and after
  satisfying liens the Brazells were to receive $327,818.54 in net proceeds.Â 
 
On December 3, 2004, Windsor or her agent notified the Brazells
  the reverse osmosis system on the property did not function.[2]Â  On December 6, 2004, the deed was
  recorded and Windsorâ€™s closing attorney forwarded the Brazells a check for the
  net proceeds.Â  Windsor withheld $2,000 from the check, noting in the memo
  section of the check that the amount reflects â€œsellerâ€™s proceeds less $2,000
  escrow for reverse osmosis system repair.â€Â  Along with the net proceeds check, Windsorâ€™s attorney also forwarded an escrow agreement proposing how the parties would
  treat the $2,000.Â  The Brazells refused to accept the check, refused to execute
  the escrow agreement, and demanded the transaction cease.
The Brazells
  filed this action alleging, inter alia, breach of contract and requesting
  rescission of the contract.Â  Windsor moved to dismiss the remedy of
  rescission.Â  The circuit court granted her motion, and the Brazells appeal.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under Rule 12(b)(6) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  a defendant may move to dismiss a complaint based on a failure to state facts
  sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  Spence v. Spence, 368 S.C.
  106, 116, 628 S.E.2d 869, 874 (2006).Â  The decision to grant a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss must be based solely upon
  the allegations set forth in the complaint. Â Id.; Clearwater Trust v. Bunting, 367 S.C. 340, 343, 626 S.E.2d 334, 335 (2006).Â  In
  deciding whether the circuit court properly granted the motion to dismiss, the
  appellate court must consider whether the complaint, viewed in the light most
  favorable to the plaintiff, states any valid claim for relief.Â  Spence, at
  116, 628 S.E.2d at 874 (2006).Â  A motion to dismiss under Rule
  12(b)(6) should not be granted if facts alleged and inferences reasonably
  deducible therefrom entitle the plaintiff to relief under any theory.Â  Id.; Overcash v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 364 S.C. 569, 572, 614 S.E.2d 619,
  620 (2005).Â  Furthermore, the complaint should not be dismissed merely because the court
  doubts the plaintiff will prevail in the action.Â  Spence, at 116-17, 628
  S.E.2d at 874.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Assumption of
  Truth in the Pleadings
The Brazells argue
  the circuit court failed to consider the allegations in the complaint as
  truthful and therefore erred in granting Windsorâ€™s motion to dismiss the remedy
  of rescission at the 12(b)(6) stage.Â  We disagree.Â   
Rescission
  is an equitable remedy that attempts to undo a contract from the beginning as
  if the contract had never existed.Â  Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C.
  78, 95, 594 S.E.2d 485, 494 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted). Â â€œIt is a
  general legal principle that a breach of contract warranting rescission â€˜must
  be so substantial and fundamental as to defeat the purpose of the contract.â€™â€Â  Rogers
    v. Salisbury Brick Corp., 299 S.C. 141, 143, 382 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1989) (citation
  omitted).Â  See also Gibbs v. G.K.H., Inc., 311 S.C. 103, 105, 427
  S.E.2d 701, 702 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Furthermore, rescission should only be
  granted when breaches defeat the object of the contracting parties and not for
  minor or casual breaches.Â  Rogers, at 143-44, 382 S.E.2d at 917 (citing Davis v.
    Cordell, 237 S.C. 88, 115 S.E.2d 649 (1960) (applying this doctrine to real
  estate transactions)); Ellie, at 95, 594 S.E.2d at 494. Â As a remedy,
  rescission should return the contracting parties to the status quo ante.Â  See Ellie, at 95, 594 S.E.2d at 494.Â  Finally,
  courts should not grant rescission where the nonmoving party has substantially
  changed position in reliance on a contract.Â  See King v. Oxford, 282 S.C. 307, 313-314, 318 S.E.2d 125, 129 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
 
Here, taking the
  facts as alleged in the complaint as true, the Brazells failed to state facts
  sufficient to justify resorting to the remedy of rescission. [3]Â 
  Their alleged minor breach of $2,000 held in escrow pending repairs is not
  substantial or fundamental enough to defeat the purpose of a $550,000 real
  estate transaction.[4]Â 
  Windsor withheld the $2,000 in lieu of requiring that the Brazells repair the
  reverse osmosis system.Â  The $2,000 withheld amounted to .04% of the total
  contract cost.Â  Furthermore, Windsor did not refuse to pay the $2,000, it was
  simply held in escrow.Â  Due to the minor alleged breach, South Carolina law
  will not afford rescission as a remedy in this case.Â   
Additionally,
  the circuit court bottomed its opinion on the difficulty that would be involved
  in returning the parties to the status quo ante.Â  While this argument
  has substantial appeal, we need not address it as we have already determined
  the claimed breach was not substantial enough in nature to warrant rescission.Â  
 
II.  Grounds not
  Stated in Initial Motion[5]
The
  Brazells further argue dismissal of the rescission remedy is improper because
  the order grants relief on grounds not stated in Windsorâ€™s 12(b)(6) motion.Â  Windsorâ€™s initial motion to dismiss was premised upon the grounds that rescission is an
  equitable remedy that could not be sought in an action at law.Â  Windsor then faxed a memorandum in support of motion to the Brazells on the day before the
  hearing raising the issues of material breach and return of the parties to the status
    quo ante.
The
  Brazells describe Windsorâ€™s actions as an â€œamendment by ambush.â€Â  However, the
  Brazells failed to move for a continuance on the day of the hearing to avoid
  any perceived â€œambush.â€Â  Consequently, the court was denied the opportunity to
  rule on this issue, and it is not preserved for our review.Â  See A
    & I, Inc. v. Gore, 366 S.C. 233, 243, 621 S.E.2d 383, 388 (Ct. App. 2005)
  (finding issue of last-minute presentation of magistrateâ€™s return not preserved
  where appellant failed to request a continuance and circuit court was therefore
  denied opportunity to rule); Mixson, Inc. v. Am. Loyalty Ins. Co., 349
  S.C. 394, 401, 562 S.E.2d 659, 663 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding grant of summary
  judgment on same day as granting motion to compel not preserved for review
  where appellant failed to move for a continuance for discovery to be completed). 
 
III.  12(b)(6) Motion Converted
  into Summary Judgment
Finally, the Brazells contend the 12(b)(6) motion was
  converted into a motion for summary judgment because the circuit court weighed
  the facts and considered the issue of material breach.Â  We disagree.Â   
Initially, we note
  the circuit court must consider the issue of material breach in order to
  determine whether to grant or deny Brazellâ€™s 12(b)(6) motion.Â  This consideration
  alone does not convert Brazellâ€™s motion into a summary judgment motion.Â  Rather,
  a 12(b)(6) motion is converted into a motion for summary judgment when the court
  goes outside the face of the complaint to rule on the motion.Â  Here, there was
  no need for the circuit court to consider evidence outside the complaint and
  its attachments to determine no material breach was alleged.Â  Furthermore, even
  if the circuit court looked outside the face of the complaint, the error would
  be harmless.Â  See Higgins v. MUSC, 326 S.C. 592, 605, 486
  S.E.2d 269, 275 (Ct. App. 1997) (indicating conversion of a 12(b)(6) motion
  into a summary judgment motion may be harmless error when, without reference to
  the matters outside of the plaintiffâ€™s complaint, dismissal can still be
  justified under Rule 12(b)(6)).Â   
AFFIRMED.Â   
SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  Windsor filed a motion to dismiss with this court
  arguing the appeal should be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.Â Â  After
  hearing argument from both parties, we deny the motion.
[2]  A reverse osmosis system is used to improve
  the smell and taste of water in places where tap water is of poor quality.Â 
 
[3]  Nakell v. Liner Yankelevitz Sunshine &
  Regenstreif, LLP, 394 F.Supp.2d 762 (M.D.N.C. 2005), has a different result
  but applies the same analysis employed in this case.Â  â€œ[T]o justify rescission
  of a contract, the breach of the contract must be so material as in effect to
  defeat the very terms of the contract.â€Â  Id. at 769.Â  In Nakell,
  the court held the counterclaim for rescission should not have been dismissed
  because the court could not determine whether there was a material breach or
  whether the parties could be returned to their original position from the
    pleadings alone. Â Id. at 771.  
[4]  Although the complaint does not contain the
  overall purchase price of the property, the HUD-1 reveals that information.
[5]  The analysis of issues involved in the first
  and second arguments on appeal are similar and are therefore combined herein.

title: State v. Frazier
description: The court determined there was sufficient substantial circumstantial evidence to submit the charge of murder to the jury and that the defendant's confrontational rights were not violated, but that the trial court should have directed a verdict of not guilty on the charge of armed robbery.
text:
THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				John Boyd Frazier, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal
  From Horry County
Paula
  H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion
  No. 4310
Heard
  October 11, 2007 â€“ Filed November 8, 2007
AFFIRMED
  IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Katherine Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
				Attorney General
  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

STILWELL,
  J.:Â 
  John Boyd Frazier appeals his convictions for murder and armed robbery claiming
  the court erred in admitting certain statements of his co-conspirator and in
  denying his motions for directed verdict on both charges. Â We affirm in part
  and reverse in part.
FACTS
Frazier was tried for
  the murder and armed robbery of William Brent Poole, the husband of Frazierâ€™s
  paramour, Renee Poole.[1] Â Brent was murdered while he and Renee walked along the shore at Myrtle Beach on the night of June 9, 1998.[2]Â 
  Officer Scott Brown of the Myrtle Beach Police Department testified that while
  on beach patrol in his truck the night of the murder he was approached by Renee.Â 
  Brown testified that Renee told him, â€œmy husband has been shot.â€ Â After briefly
  examining the scene and realizing Brent had in fact been shot, Brown escorted
  Renee back to his truck and radioed dispatch.Â  As he did so, Renee â€œkept
  touching her chest and saying â€˜we were robbed.â€™â€Â  As he was talking to
  dispatch, Brown asked Renee to describe the killer. Â She told him the suspect
  was wearing all black clothes and a ski mask and had instructed them to lie
  face down on the beach
The trial judge had
  initially agreed to allow the testimony regarding Reneeâ€™s statements at the
  scene over Frazierâ€™s objection that the statements were testimonial in nature,
  and Renee was not available for cross-examination.Â  However, upon
  reconsideration the trial judge determined the testimony regarding all of
  Reneeâ€™s statements except â€œmy husband has been shotâ€ should be stricken from
  the record.Â  The trial judge then offered a curative instruction to the jury, and
  the trial proceeded.  
The State called Donna
  and Mark Hobbes who testified that as they exited the Carolina Winds Motel to
  go for a walk on the beach the night of the murder, they noticed a man they
  later described as being â€œsuspicious.â€Â  Mark testified that the man stared at
  them, and he stared back until the man turned and moved quickly in the
  direction of the beach.Â  Donna testified that she noticed the man because he
  was running and because he had on dark, heavy clothing that seemed
  inappropriate for the weather.Â  As the Hobbeses walked toward the beach access
  point, which consisted of a short boardwalk and steps down to the strand, Donna
  saw the man again crouched behind the motel. Â The man then stood and looked straight
  at the couple so that both the Hobbeses were able to see his face. Â They testified
  the man then ran in the general direction of the beach but toward an area where
  there was heavy vegetation rather than the clear, sandy portion of the beach. Â The
  couple later, both in independent photographic lineups and in court, identified
  Frazier as the â€œsuspiciousâ€ man.Â  Both indicated they were confident in their
  identification.
Frazierâ€™s supervisor
  testified that the week prior to the murder, Frazier had requested June 8, 9,
  and 10 off from work.Â  Frazier offered no alibi for the night of the murder other
  than telling officers he was home alone sick.Â  Captain William Frontz testified
  that pursuant to a search warrant copies of a day planner were discovered at
  Frazierâ€™s home. Â The day planner contained a notation on June 9: Â â€œRenee and Brent.â€Â 
  Other writing was above that notation but had been marked out.Â  Bruce Wolford,
  a friend of Frazier, testified that Frazier hated Brent and the control he
  exercised over Renee by virtue of their sharing a young daughter. Â Wolford also
  testified that Renee and Frazier were together at Wolfordâ€™s home during the
  time period before the murder when Renee and Frazier were allegedly no longer
  romantically involved.Â  Wolford overheard the pair discussing the fact that
  Renee and Brent were planning a trip to the beach.Â  Renee and Brentâ€™s neighbor,
  James Bollow, testified that a black Chevrolet Blazer, the vehicle he had seen
  Frazier in previously, had been at the Poole home during Brentâ€™s work hours and
  during the days leading up to the murder.
It was further shown
  that Frazier had previously owned a gun that could not be excluded as the
  murder weapon.[3]Â 
  Frazier could not account for the whereabouts of the gun, indicating he had
  sold it at a gun show.Â  The State also showed that Frazier had borrowed a
  vehicle from a friend the day before the murder and returned it the day after
  the murder.Â  Frazier told that same friend upon returning the vehicle that
  Brent had been â€œshot and killedâ€ even though Frazierâ€™s contact with police to
  that point had not involved any discussion of Brent having been shot.
Finally, the State
  presented the testimony of Howard Sirles who testified that he discovered
  Brentâ€™s soaking wet wallet on July 5 in his yard located across the road from
  the beach area that contained the murder scene.[4] Â Officer David Blubaugh testified the wallet contained Brentâ€™s driverâ€™s
  license, $9 cash, two ATM cards, photographs, and other miscellaneous items.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Testimony of
  Officer Brown
Frazier contends
  the trial judge erred in admitting, through the testimony of Officer Brown,
  Reneeâ€™s statement â€œmy husband has been shot.â€Â  We disagree.Â  Before delving
  into a lengthy Crawford[5] analysis, it becomes apparent that the propriety of the trial judgeâ€™s ruling on
  this issue is not preserved for our review. Â The trial judge initially allowed
  testimony regarding Reneeâ€™s statements to Officer Brown immediately after the
  murder finding them to be non-testimonial.Â  After reconsidering the issue, the
  trial judge informed the jury that all statements other than â€œmy husband has
  been shotâ€ would be stricken from the record and could not be considered as
  evidence.Â  The attorneys and the trial judge agreed this was an acceptable way
  for this matter to be dealt with, and Frazier offered no objection even after
  the judge read the verbatim curative instruction she planned to give the jury.Â 
  In order to preserve such an issue for our review where a curative instruction
  was offered, an appellant must make a contemporaneous objection to the
  sufficiency of the instruction or make a motion for mistrial.Â  State v.
    Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 658-59, 623 S.E.2d 122, 130 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In this
  instance, the curative instruction specifically allowed for the inclusion of
  the statement â€œmy husband has been shot.â€Â  Not having objected to that portion
  of the curative instruction, nor having moved for a mistrial, Frazier cannot
  now claim error in the admission of the statement. Â 
II.Â  Denial of
  Directed Verdict Motionâ€”Murder
When reviewing the denial of a directed verdict, this court must
  view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to
  the state.Â  State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648
  (2006).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence
  reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must
  find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Id. at 292-93, 625 S.E.2d at 648.Â  â€œWhen the state relies exclusively on
  circumstantial evidence and a motion for directed verdict is made, the circuit
  court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its
  weight.â€Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478
  (2004).Â  The court should grant a directed verdict motion when the evidence presented
  merely raises a suspicion of guilt.Â  Id.Â  â€œâ€˜Suspicionâ€™ implies a belief
  or opinion as to guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to
  proof.Â  However, a trial judge is not required to find that the
    evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).

In this instance, the
  State built its murder case out of numerous pieces of circumstantial evidence
  coupled with the identification of the Hobbeses.Â  Testimony regarding Frazierâ€™s
  ongoing, adulterous relationship with Renee and hatred of Brent provided
  evidence of motive.Â  The prosecution presented evidence that the relationship
  continued up until the time of Brentâ€™s murder, even though Renee and Frazier
  were supposedly no longer a couple.Â  

Testimony about Frazier
  asking for time off from work and his lack of a corroborated alibi on the night
  in question was evidence of opportunity.Â  In addition, there was testimony that
  Renee and Frazier discussed the beach trip and that the date of the trip was indicated
  on Frazierâ€™s calendar with the notation, â€œRenee and Brent.â€Â  Furthermore, a
  friend of Frazierâ€™s testified that Frazier borrowed a car for the three-day
  period around the time of the murder.Â  Upon returning the car to his friend,
  Frazier stated that Brent had been shot.Â  The source of his knowledge of that
  information is not revealed in the record, but the record shows he had not been
  informed by police that Brent had been shot. Â Â 

The State offered
  evidence that Frazier had the means to commit the murder in that he owned a gun
  that could have been the murder weapon.Â  Finally, there is the Hobbesesâ€™ unwavering
  testimony placing Frazier at Renee and Brentâ€™s hotel and close to the murder scene
  at the relevant time.Â  This is in contrast to Frazierâ€™s claim to police that he
  had not been to Myrtle Beach in four years.Â  Taken together, these things amount
  to more than a mere suspicion Frazier committed the crime.Â  It was within the
  juryâ€™s province to determine if the evidence established proof of guilt beyond
  a reasonable doubt, and they concluded that it did.Â  We conclude the trial judge
  did not err in denying Frazierâ€™s motion for directed verdict.
III.  Denial of
  Directed Verdict Motionâ€”Armed Robbery
â€œRobbery is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking
  of money, goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of
  another in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€Â  State
    v. Parker, 351 S.C. 567, 570, 571 S.E.2d 288, 289Â  (2002) (overruled on
  other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005)).Â  Armed
  robbery occurs when a person commits a robbery while armed with a deadly weapon,
  while using a representation of a deadly weapon, or while using an object the
  victim reasonably believed was a deadly weapon.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A)
  (Rev. 2003).  
We have reviewed the record for evidence to support the
  trial courtâ€™s denial of Frazierâ€™s directed verdict motion on the armed robbery
  charge.Â  While there admittedly is evidence that could support a robbery
  charge, we do not believe the evidence rises above the level of creating a mere
  suspicion that Frazier committed an armed robbery.Â  Pooleâ€™s wallet was
  discovered in Mr. Sirlesâ€™ yard almost a month after the murder, with no
  fingerprints or any evidence to connect it to Frazier. Â The contents of the
  wallet appeared to be intact.Â  A wedding ring was found in the sand near
  Brentâ€™s body, but there is no testimony in the record to identify that ring as
  belonging to the deceased.[6]
Had
  Reneeâ€™s statements to Officer Brown indicating a robbery had been committed been
  allowed, we would be presented with an altogether different analysis.Â  However,
  absent those statements, or any substantial circumstantial evidence connecting
  Frazier to an armed robbery of Brent Poole, we are left to merely speculate how
  the wallet found its way to Mr. Sirlesâ€™ yard.Â  The meager facts and
  circumstances the jury was left to rely upon do no more than create a mere
  suspicion of guilt.Â  A directed verdict motion should be granted when the
  evidence presented merely raises a suspicion of guilt.Â  Therefore, the trial
  courtâ€™s denial of Frazierâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the charge of
  armed robbery was error.
For all of the
  foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED
  IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] This is Frazierâ€™s second trial on these charges.Â  The South Carolina
  Supreme Court reversed and remanded Frazierâ€™s original conviction because
  certain expert evidence was not admitted and certain unreliable, hearsay
  statements by a co-worker were admitted.Â  State v. Frazier, 357 S.C.
  161, 592 S.E.2d 621 (2004).
[2] The parties were all residents of Winston-Salem, North Carolina.Â  Brent
  and Renee had come to Myrtle Beach to celebrate their wedding anniversary.
[3] The murder weapon was never discovered, but through ballistics analysis
  of the fired bullets the Stateâ€™s forensic expert could determine that the
  murder weapon was likely one of a list of 38 guns.
[4] Sirlesâ€™ prior deposition testimony was read into the record because he
  was unable to attend the trial due to health problems.Â   
[5] Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004).
[6] In the
  Stateâ€™s closing argument the solicitor characterizes the wedding ring as
  belonging to Brent, and there is no objection from Frazier.Â  We cannot, however,
  ascertain in the record any direct testimony identifying the ring as belonging
  to Brent.

title: Green Tree Servicing v. Adams
description: This case addresses the effect of failure to serve a junior lienholder.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Green Tree Servicing, LLC as successor in interest to Green Tree Financial Servicing Corp., Respondent,
				v.
				Tom Adams, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4311
Â  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November 20, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Tobias G. Ward, Jr. and J. Derrick Jackson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
				David Randolph Whitt, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:Â  Green Tree Servicing, LLC (Green Tree) filed this action against Tom Adams, seeking to clear title on property purchased by Green Tree at a foreclosure sale.Â  The circuit court declared the property free and clear of Adamsâ€™ lien.Â  Adams appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On May 26, 1999, Kenny Claxton executed a note from Green Tree for $68,400.Â  A mortgage was recorded in the Register of Deeds office on June 14, 1999, securing the note.Â  Thereafter, on August 26, 2004, Adams obtained a judgment against Claxton in the amount of $199,999.98 and duly recorded and indexed the judgment on September 4, 2004.[2]  
Claxton defaulted on the Green Tree note, and on October 26, 2004, Green Tree commenced an action for foreclosure.Â  Green Tree did not serve Adams or name him as a party to the action. Â On January 18, 2005, a hearing was held before the master-in-equity.Â  Green Tree waived its right to a deficiency judgment.Â  Green Tree purchased the property at public auction for $58,583.Â  The amount of Green Treeâ€™s debt was $80,904.44.Â  The master entered a report and confirmation of the sale on February 28, 2005.Â  
 
Green Tree discovered Adamsâ€™ judgment lien in June of 2005 and filed a â€œRule to Show Cause and Petition ancillary proceedingâ€ to add Adams as a party to the foreclosure action. Â On December 19, 2005, the master entered an order stating he no longer had subject matter jurisdiction to add Adams as a party to the case.
Green Tree then filed this action to clear title in circuit court. Â The court denied Adamsâ€™ motion to dismiss and Adams counterclaimed seeking to foreclose his judgment lien. Â Adams stipulated he would have been unable and unwilling to bid at the foreclosure sale and further stipulated the value of the property was less than Green Treeâ€™s debt.Â  The circuit court bound Adams to the previous foreclosure proceedings and cleared Green Treeâ€™s property from Adamsâ€™ judgment lien. Â Adams appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to remove a cloud on and quiet title to land is one in equity.â€Â  Bryan v. Freeman, 253 S.C. 50, 52, 168 S.E.2d 793, 793 (1969). In an action in equity, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Binding a Non-Party to a Foreclosure Action Thereby Extinguishing a Lien
Adams first argues the circuit court cannot bind him to a foreclosure action to which he was not a party, thereby extinguishing his lien.Â  We agree in part but find no reversible error.Â 
 
A court may not act against a party without personal jurisdiction.Â  BB&T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 503 (2006).Â  Moreover, a court should not render a judgment affecting the rights of a party without proper notice.Â  Ex Parte South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 350 S.C. 404, 407, 566 S.E.2d 196, 198 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Accordingly, the circuit court cannot bind Adams to the prior judgment.Â  Â Â 
However, the circuit court properly exercised personal jurisdiction over Adams in the subsequent action to clear title. Â Green Tree served Adams in this action and Adams fully participated by defending and counterclaiming for relief.Â  
 
Likewise, the circuit court properly concluded Adams has no recourse against Green Tree or the property.Â  First, Adams declined to exercise any possible right of redemption by stipulating that the value of the property was less than the amount owed to Green Tree and that he had neither the ability nor the willingness to buy the property. Â See 27 S.C. Jurisprudence Â§ 109, at 247-48 (1996) (â€œAn omitted junior lienholder retains his right of redemption, giving him the right to tender to the buyer at the senior foreclosure sale the balance which was owed on the senior lien at the time of the foreclosure.â€).Â  Id. at 248 (â€œRedemption requires payment of the entire debt that has accrued upon the senior mortgage. . . regardless of whether the property brought less at the foreclosure sale.â€). Therefore, Green Treeâ€™s failure to serve Adams or make him a party to the foreclosure action did not prejudice Adams.Â  Although Adams cannot enforce his lien against this property, his judgment is not extinguished but is still of record. Â Adams simply must seek relief on his judgment from another source.Â Â Â Â Â  
 
II.Â  Union National Bank v. Cook
Adams next argues the circuit court erred in relying on Union National Bank of Columbia v. Cook, 110 S.C. 99, 96 S.E. 484 (1918).Â  We disagree.Â  
 
The circuit court quoted the following language from Union National Bank:Â  
 

	But it should appear to the Court that the junior incumbrancer has a substantial right in the land to be protected and his lien enforced for some practical purpose, and not merely the prosecution of a fictitious cause of action. In other words, it must appear to the court prima facie that the land is worth more than prior incumbrances and that in probability upon a resale of the land the proceeds would reach the claim of the junior incumbrancer.

Id. at 115, 96 S.E. at 488.Â  The circuit court cited this language to emphasize that the debt Claxton owed to Green Tree substantially exceeded the foreclosed propertyâ€™s value such that any resale of the property would not benefit Adams as a junior lien holder.Â  Like the lienholder in Union National Bank, Adams is unable to show how his absence from the foreclosure action prejudiced him. 
 
III.Â  Statutory Language
Adams finally argues his lien can only be extinguished, pursuant to section 15-39-880 of the South Carolina Code, by naming him as a party in the foreclosure action.Â  We disagree.Â  
 

	Section 15-39-880 provides:
	
		No lien created by operation of law . . . shall constitute a lien or attach or reattach as a lien on real property of the lien debtor or real property in which the lien debtor has an interest after a public sale of such real property at any execution or judicial sale in any action or special proceeding to which the lien creditor is duly made a party as provided by law. But this section and Â§ 15-39-890 shall not be construed to affect any prior mortgage lien not foreclosed in any such action or special proceeding and shall not be construed to require the foreclosure of any such prior mortgage lien . . . .
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-880 (2005).Â  Adams again maintains his lien was improperly extinguished in the foreclosure action.Â  As explained above, the foreclosure action did not improperly extinguish Adamsâ€™ lien.Â  Rather, this proceeding removed the lien and cleared title to that property.Â  Adamsâ€™ judgment remains viable and on the judgment roll.
Finally, our supreme court addressed the necessity of making a junior lien holder a party under similar facts in Peeples v. Snyder, stating:Â  
 

	
		The first mortgagee had the legal right to foreclose his mortgage without making the second mortgagee a party to the action. While the second mortgagee, under the circumstances, was a 
		proper party, she was not a necessary party; and however expedient it may have been, and was, to have made her a party, as this case has demonstrated, in order that all questions might be determined in the one action, the omission did not affect the validity of the foreclosure proceedings; it only affected the 
		effectiveness of it in leaving open, undetermined, the rights of the second mortgagee.
	

141 S.C. 152, 156, 139 S.E. 405, 406 (1927) (emphasis in original).Â  As in Peeples, the omission of Adams in the foreclosure proceedings did not invalidate the sale.Â  Rather, it merely left Adamsâ€™ rights as to the Green Tree property undetermined, which have now been addressed in this case.Â  As previously noted, his judgment against Claxton remains viable. 
 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is  
AFFIRMED.  
STILWELL and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.  

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Adamsâ€™ mortgage was recorded again on December 7, 2004.Â

title: State v. Tumbleston
description: In this criminal appeal, two issues are presented: 1) Did Appellantâ€™s four indictments, which alleged separate, undated events over the course of several years, not give him adequate notice of charges to prepare a defense; and (2)  Did the circuit court err by denying Appellantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, when the   Stateâ€™s evidence was insufficient to show that Appellant committed the alleged offenses?
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINAIn The Court of Appeals
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Vernon Tumbleston, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â J. C. â€œBuddyâ€ Nicholson, Jr., Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4312
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed November 27,
  2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and
  Assistant Attorney General Julie Thames, all of Columbia; and Scarlett Anne
  Wilson of Charleston, Â for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.: Vernon Tumbleston appeals his convictions for first- degree criminal sexual
  conduct with a minor and committing a lewd act on a minor, arguing the trial court erred in denying his motion to quash the indictments.Â 
  Specifically, Tumbleston maintains the indictments did
  not allege the specific time of each offense intended to be charged, and thus, failed
  to provide him with adequate notice to prepare a defense.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The present
  case revolves around the accusations of Tumblestonâ€™s granddaughter, B.J., who
  was ten years old at the time of Tumblestonâ€™s trial.Â  In late 2004, B.J. told
  her mother Tumbleston had repeatedly molested her over the course of several
  years.Â  The violation began when she was in kindergarten and continued
  throughout the second grade.Â  B.J. alleged Tumbleston â€œlicked [her] private,â€
  â€œstuck his private in [her] private,â€ â€œstuck his private in [her] mouth,â€ and
  â€œputÂ  [her] hand on his private.â€Â  B.J. claimed these acts occurred more than
  once over the three-year period.Â  B.J. did not tell her mother about the
  abuse until approximately three years after it began, when she refused to go
  shopping with Tumbleston.Â  After hearing B.J.â€™s account of the sexual abuse, B.J.â€™s
  mother took her to a local pediatrician and the Lowcountry Childrenâ€™s Center
  for examination.Â  Subsequently, a representative from â€œPeople Against Rapeâ€
  notified the North Charleston Police Department of B.J.â€™s accusations.Â  During the
  police investigation, Tumbleston agreed to give an oral statement regarding his
  alleged molestation of B.J.Â  According to Tumbleston, â€œthere [was] a
  possibility that he might have touched [B.J.] between her legs while he was
  asleep.â€Â  Additionally, â€œit [was] possible [Tumblestonâ€™s] penis came out of his
  pants and touched [B.J.].â€Â   
Tumbleston
  was indicted on four counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a
  minor and one count of committing a lewd act on a minor.Â  The indictments
  alleged the charged offenses occurred between 2001 and 2004.Â  Tumbleston moved
  to quash the indictments on the ground of insufficiency, asserting the indictments failed to indicate the specific time of each offense,
  thus depriving him of adequate notice.Â  Despite Tumblestonâ€™s contention, the trial court found
  the indictments sufficient as long as the State â€œtie[d] in the dates of the
  time frame with some type of rational testimony from other people.â€Â   
The
  jury found Tumbleston guilty on two counts of first-degree criminal sexual
  conduct with a minor and one count of committing a lewd act on a minor.Â  The court directed a verdict of not guilty on one count
  of criminal sexual conduct, and the jury acquitted Tumbleston on another count
  of criminal sexual conduct.Â  The
  trial court sentenced Tumbleston to concurrent terms of imprisonment totaling
  twenty-two years followed by five years probation.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  trial courtâ€™s factual conclusions as to the sufficiency of an indictment will
  not be disturbed on appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse
  of discretion.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220
  (2006).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.Â  Id.; see also State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 506, 626 S.E.2d 59, 63 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted June 7,
  2007; State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384
  (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Accordingly, an appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s
  factual findings when the findings are supported by the evidence and not controlled
  by error of law.Â  Baccus, 367 S.C. at 48, 625 S.E.2d at 220; Douglas, 367 S.C. at 506, 626 S.E.2d at 63. 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Insufficient Indictment
Tumbleston
  avers the trial court erred in denying his motion to quash the indictments on
  the ground of insufficiency. Â Tumbleston contends the indictments did not
  allege the specific time of each offense intended to be charged, and therefore,
  failed to provide him with adequate notice to prepare a defense.Â  We
  disagree.  
A.
  The Indictment: A â€œNotice Documentâ€
In State
  v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 101-02, 610 S.E.2d 494, 499 (2005), our
  supreme court â€œabandoned the view that, in criminal matters, the circuit court
  acquires subject matter jurisdiction to hear a particular case by way of a
  valid [grand jury] indictment.â€Â  State v. Means, 367 S.C. 374, 381, 626
  S.E.2d 348, 352 (2006). Â Prior to Gentry, the circuit court did not have
  subject matter jurisdiction in a criminal case unless: (1) there was an
  indictment sufficiently stating an offense; (2) the defendant waived
  presentment of the indictment to the grand jury; or (3) the charge was a lesser-included
  offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  Means, 367 S.C. at 381,
  626 S.E.2d at 352; Evans v. State, 363 S.C. 495, 507-09, 611 S.E.2d 510,
  516-18 (2005); Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362-63, 495 S.E.2d 773,
  777 (1998); Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359
  (1995); State
    v. Beachum, 288 S.C. 325, 326, 342 S.E.2d 597, 598 (1986); Summerall v.
      State, 278 S.C. 255, 256, 294 S.E.2d 344, 344 (1982); State v. Tabory,
  262 S.C. 136, 139-40, 202 S.E.2d 852, 853 (1974).Â Â  Consequently, a defective
  or insufficient indictment often resulted in the lack of subject matter
  jurisdiction, â€œwhich is a matter that may be raised at any time, including on
  direct appeal, in a [post-conviction relief] action or sua sponte by the trial or appellate courts.â€Â  Means,
    367 S.C. at 381, 626 S.E.2d at 352; see also State v. Munn, 292
    S.C. 497, 499, 357 S.E.2d 461, 463 (1987) (concluding trial court lacks subject
    matter jurisdiction to convict defendant for an offense if there is no indictment
    charging him with the offense when the jury is sworn).
As our supreme court recognized in Gentry, the subject
  matter jurisdiction of the circuit court and the sufficiency of an indictment
  are two distinct concepts.Â  Gentry, 363 S.C. at 102 n.6, 610 S.E.2d at
  499 n.6 (â€œ[P]resentment of an indictment or a waiver of presentment is not
  needed to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court.â€).Â  â€œSubject
  matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the
  general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Gentry, 363
  S.C. at 100, 610 S.E.2d at 498; Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 150, 526
  S.E.2d 222, 227 (2000); Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235,
  237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994); see also S.C. Const. art. V,
  Â§ 11 (providing circuit court â€œshall be a general trial court with original
  jurisdiction in civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive
  jurisdiction shall be given to inferior courts, and shall have such appellate
  jurisdiction as provided by lawâ€).  
â€œHowever, an indictment is needed to give notice to the
  defendant of the charges against him.â€Â  Gentry, 363 S.C. at 102 n.6, 610
  S.E.2d at 499 n.6. (Emphasis added).Â  Definitively, an indictment is a â€œnotice document.â€ Â See S.C. Const. art.
  I, Â§ 11 (â€œNo person may be held to answer for any crime the jurisdiction over
  which is not within the magistrateâ€™s court, unless on a presentment or
  indictment of a grand jury of the county where the crime has been committed. .
  . .â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-10 (2003) (â€œNo person shall be held to answer in
  any court for an alleged crime or offense, unless upon indictment by a grand
  jury. . . .â€).Â  Indeed,  

	[t]he indictment is the
  charge of the state against the defendant, the pleading by which he is informed
  of the fact, and the nature and scope of the accusation.Â  When that indictment
  is presented, that accusation made, that pleading filed, the accused has two
  courses of procedure open to him. Â He may question the propriety of the
  accusation, the manner in which it has been presented, the source from which it
  proceeds, and have these matters promptly and properly determined; or, waiving
  them, he may put in issue the truth of the accusation, and demand the judgment
  of his peers on the merits of the charge. Â If he omits the former, and chooses
  the latter, he ought not, when defeated on the latter,-when found guilty of the
  crime charged,-to be permitted to go back to the former, and inquire as to the
  manner and means by which the
  charge was presented.

Gentry, 363 S.C. at 102, 610 S.E.2d at 499-500 (quoting State v.
  Faile, 43 S.C. 52, 59-60, 20 S.E. 798, 801 (1895), overruled on other
    grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315
      (1991)). 
Pursuant to Gentry, an indictment reputed to be insufficient
  no longer raises a question of subject matter jurisdiction; rather, it raises a question of whether
  a defendant properly received notice he would be tried for a particular crime.Â  See Evans, 363 S.C. at 507-09, 611 S.E.2d at 516-17; see also State v. Smalls, 364 S.C. 343, 346-48, 613 S.E.2d 754, 756-57 (2005)
  (holding circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to accept a guilty plea
  where defendant was not indicted for the charge to which he pled guilty, but
  signed a sentencing sheet which established defendant was notified of the
  charge to which he pled guilty).Â  
 
B.  Sufficiency of the Indictment
A
  challenge to the sufficiency of an indictment must be made before the jury is
  sworn.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (2003).Â  If the objection is timely made, the
  circuit court should evaluate the sufficiency of the indictment by determining
  whether (1) the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity
  to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to
  know what he is called upon to answer and whether
  he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon; and (2) whether it apprises
  the defendant of the elements of the offense intended to be charged.Â  Gentry,
  363 S.C. at 102-03, 610 S.E.2d at 500 (citing State v. Wilkes, 353 S.C.
  462, 465, 578 S.E.2d 717, 719 (2003)).Â  A ruling on a timely objection, before
  the jury is sworn, that an indictment is not sufficient will result in the
  quashing of the indictment unless the defendant waives presentment to the grand
  jury and pleads guilty. Â Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 155, 580 S.E.2d
  120, 122-23 (2003), overruled on other grounds by Gentry,
  363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494; Hopkins v. State, 317 S.C. 7, 10, 451
  S.E.2d 389, 390 (1994), overruled on other grounds by Gentry, 363
  S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494.Â   
In determining whether an indictment meets the sufficiency
  standard, the trial court must look at the indictment with a practical eye in
  view of all the surrounding circumstances.Â  See State v. Means,
  367 S.C. 374, 383, 626 S.E.2d 348, 353-54 (2006); Gentry, 363 S.C. at
  103, 610 S.E.2d at 500; State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75,
  78 (1993); State v. Wade, 306 S.C. 79, 83, 409 S.E.2d 780, 782 (1991); State
    v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 108, 572 S.E.2d 309, 312 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing State
      v. Adams, 277 S.C. 115, 126, 283 S.E.2d 582, 588 (1981); State v.
        Reddick, 348 S.C. 631, 637, 560 S.E.2d 441, 444 (Ct. App. 2002); see
          also Evans, 363 S.C. at 507-09, 611 S.E.2d at 516-17 (noting all the
  surrounding circumstances must be weighed to make an accurate determination of
  whether the defendant was prejudiced by a lack of notice and an insufficient
  indictment).Â  Accordingly, the sufficiency of an indictment is examined
  objectively, from the viewpoint of a reasonable person, and not from the subjective
  viewpoint of a particular defendant.Â  Means, 367 S.C. at 383, 626 S.E.2d
  at 353-54.Â  Further, whether the indictment could be more definite or certain
  is irrelevant. Â Gentry, 363 S.C. at 102-03, 610 S.E.2d at 500.Â  As repeatedly noted by our appellate courts:

	An
  indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with [enough] certainty and
  particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the
  defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an
  acquittal or conviction thereon. Â The true test of the sufficiency of an
  indictment is not whether it could be made more definite and
  certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended
  to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be
  prepared to meet.Â  

See Means, 367 S.C. at 383, 626 S.E.2d at 353-54; Gentry, 363 S.C. at 102-03, 610 S.E.2d at 500; State
  v. Ham, 259 S.C. 118, 191 S.E.2d 13 (1972); State v.
    Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 661, 623 S.E.2d 122, 131 (Ct. App. 2005); State
      v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 374, 580 S.E.2d 785, 792 (Ct. App. 2003); Guthrie,
  352 S.C. at 108, 572 S.E.2d at 312.  

	In South Carolina, an
  indictment
	shall
  be deemed and judged sufficient and good in law which, in addition to
  allegations as to time and place, as required by law, charges the crime substantially in the
  language of the common law or of the statute prohibiting the crime or so
  plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood and, if
  the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense be alleged to be contrary
  to the statute in such case made and provided.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20
  (2003); see also State
    v. Pierce, 263 S. C. 23, 27, 207 S.
  E. 2d 414, 416 (1974); State
    v. Quarles, 261 S. C. 413, 417, 200 S. E. 2d 384, 386 (1973); State v.
      Rutledge, 232 S.C. 223, 225, 101 S.E.2d 289, 292 (1957).Â  Therefore, an indictment passes legal muster when it charges the
  crime substantially in the language of the statute prohibiting the crime or so
  plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood.Â  Reddick,
  348 S.C. at 635, 560 S.E.2d at 443; State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 355,
  510 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. App. 1998) overruled on other grounds by Gentry,
  363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494.
1.Â 
  Specific Time of Offenses Charged
While our supreme court has not created a new rule or standard for
  addressing this issue, this court has adopted a two-prong test for determining
  the sufficiency of an indictment involving a purportedly overbroad time period:
  (1) whether time is a material element of the offense; and (2) whether the time
  period covered by the indictment occurred prior to the return of the indictment
  by the grand jury.Â  State
    v. Nicholson, 366 S.C. 568, 574, 623 S.E.2d 100, 103 (Ct. App.
  2005) (holding an indictment alleging commission of second-degree criminal
  conduct during periods of June 1 through July 20, 1995; July 1 through July 31,
  1995; and August 1 through August 18, 1995, was sufficient as to time); State
    v. Wingo, 304 S.C. 173, 175, 403 S.E.2d 322, 323 (Ct. App. 1991) (finding an indictment charging first-degree criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor covering a two-year period was sufficient as to
  time); see also State v. Thompson, 305
  S.C. 496, 500-01, 409 S.E.2d 420, 423 (Ct. App. 1991) (â€œThe
  specific date and time is not an element of the offense of first-degree
  criminal sexual conduct.â€).
Contrary
  to Tumblestonâ€™s contention, the indictments need not specify the precise time of
  each offense charged because (1) time is not a material element of each offense;
  and (2) the three-year
  time period covered by the indictments occurred prior to the return of the
  indictments by the grand jury.Â  Nicholson, 366
  S.C. at 574, 623 S.E.2d at 103; see also State v. Ray,
  24 S.C.L. (Rice) 1, 4-5 (1838) (â€œIf the time laid in the indictment is
  antecedent to the finding, in general it is not material that the [offense]
  should be proven to have been committed either before or after the time laid â€”
  provided it was a reasonable time before the finding of the grand jury.â€); 65
  Am. Jur. 2d Rape Â§ 34, at 582 (2001) (â€œBecause time is not an essential
  ingredient of either forcible or statutory rape, the exact date of the
  commission of the offense need not be alleged unless a statute provides
  otherwise.â€); 75 C.J.S. Rape Â§ 45, at 515-16 (1952) (stating it is
  proper and sufficient to prove the commission of a sexual assault on any day
  before the indictment and within the period of limitations and, in cases
  involving a victim under the age of consent, on a day when the victim was still
  under the statutory age).
In
  the case sub judice, Tumbleston was charged with four counts of first-degree
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor and one count of committing a lewd act on
  a minor. Â Section 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code of Laws sets forth the
  statutory provision for first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor as
  follows:  

	(A)  A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct with a minor
  in the first degree if:
	(1)  the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is
  less than eleven years of age; or
	(2)  the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is
  less than sixteen years of age and the actor has previously been convicted of,
  pled guilty or nolo contendere to, or adjudicated delinquent for an offense
  listed in Section 23-3-430(C) or has been ordered to be included in the sex
  offender registry pursuant to Section 23-3-430(D).

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (Supp.
  2006).

	â€œSexual
  batteryâ€ means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, anal intercourse, or
  any intrusion, however slight, of any part of a personâ€™s body or of any object
  into the genital or anal openings of another personâ€™s body, except when such
  intrusion is accomplished for medically recognized treatment or diagnostic
  purposes.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h)
  (2003).Â   
The crime of
  committing or attempting to commit a lewd act on a child under sixteen is set
  forth in section 16-15-140 as follows:Â   

	It
  is unlawful for a person over the age of fourteen years to wilfully and lewdly
  commit or attempt a lewd or lascivious act upon or with the body, or its parts,
  of a child under the age of sixteen years, with the intent of arousing,
  appealing to, or gratifying the lust or passions or sexual desires of the
  person or of the child.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-140 (2003).

	The indictments
  against Tumbleston claimed:
	Indictment
  2005-GS-10-807: That
  [appellant] did in Charleston County on or between 2001 and June 2004 engage in
  sexual battery upon [B.J.], date of birth 1-23-96, to wit: fellatio.Â  This is
  in violation of Â§ 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (1976) as
  amended. [1]
	Indictment
  2005-GS-10-808: That [appellant] did in Charleston County on or between 2001 and June 2004
  engage in sexual battery upon [B.J.], date of birth 1-23-96, to wit:
  cunnilingus.Â  This is in violation of Â§ 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code of
  Laws (1976) as amended.
	Indictment
  2005-GS-10-809: That [appellant] did in Charleston County on or between 2001 and June 2004
  engage in sexual battery upon [B.J.], date of birth 1-23-96, to wit: digital
  penetration.Â  This is in violation of Â§ 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code of
  Laws (1976) as amended. [2]
	Indictment
  2005-GS-10-810:Â 
  That [appellant] did in Charleston County on or between 2001 and June 2004
  engage in sexual battery upon [B.J.], date of birth 1-23-96, to wit: sexual
  intercourse.Â  This is in violation of Â§ 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code of
  Laws (1976) as amended.
	Indictment
  2005-GS-10-811: That [appellant] did in Charleston County on or between 2001 and June 2004
  willfully and lewdly commit or attempt a lewd and lascivious act upon or with
  the body of one [B.J.], a child under the age of sixteen years, with the intent
  of arousing, appealing to, and gratifying the lust, passions, and sexual
  desires of himself or such child.Â  This is in violation of Â§ 16-15-140 of the
  South Carolina Code of Laws (1976) as amended.Â  

The
  indictments clearly identify the elements of each offense charged,
  substantially tracking the statutory language so plainly that the nature of the
  offense charged can be easily understood.Â  Each indictment establishes an
  offense of sexual battery as defined in section 16-3-651 or lewd act on a minor
  as defined in section 16-15-140.Â  The victimâ€™s date of birth substantiates that
  she was under the age of eleven when the offenses occurred. Â The conduct charged
  occurred â€œon or between 2001 and June 2004.â€Â  Furthermore, the indictments indicate
  the offenses occurred prior to the February 15, 2005 grand jury indictment.Â  
 
Time is not a material element of either first-degree criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor or committing a lewd act on a minor.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-3-655, 16-15-140 (2003 and Supp. 2006).Â  The State is not required to denote the precise day, or even year, of the accused conduct in an
  indictment charging criminal sexual conduct. Â Thompson, 305 S.C. at 501,
  409 S.E.2d at 423. Â Indeed, indictments for a sex crime that allege offenses
  occurred during a specified time period are sufficient when the circumstances
  of the case warrant considering an extended time frame.Â  Nicholson, 366
  S.C. at 574, 623 S.E.2d at 103; see also State v.
    Alexander, 140 S.C. 325, 138 S.E. 835, 839 (1927) (noting â€œsurplusage will
  not vitiate an indictment which, without regard to the surplusage, is
  sufficient to charge the offense for which the defendant is being indictedâ€).Â  
 
The stealth and repetitive nature of the alleged conduct compels
  identification of the broader time period.Â  The victim is a young child, whom
  one cannot reasonably expect to recall the exact dates of the sexual abuse.Â  B.J.
  verified the abuse began while she was in kindergarten, and she ensured the end
  of the abuse when she disclosed the offenses to her mother.Â Â Â   
We reject the notion that a specified time period prevented Tumbleston
  from adequately preparing his defense to the charges. Â Reading the indictments
  objectively from a reasonable personâ€™s view, we conclude they contain the
  necessary elements of the offenses charged and sufficiently apprise Tumbleston
  that he must be prepared to address his conduct toward B.J. between 2001 and
  June 2004.
Tumbleston
  proceeded with the defense of denial, and the jury simply rejected this defense.
  His contention regarding the sufficiency of the indictments is without merit
  and we discern no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â   
II.  Motion for
  Directed Verdict
Tumbleston maintains the trial court erred in denying his motion
  for a directed verdict.Â  However, Tumbleston failed to argue or identify supporting authority on this issue
  in his brief on appeal.Â  Consequently, we deem this issue abandoned.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363 444 S.E.2d 513, 515 (1994)
  (stating an issue is abandoned where the appellant fails to provide argument or
  supporting authority); see also Fassett v. Evans, 364 S.C. 42,
  45, 610 S.E.2d 841, 844 (Ct. App. 2005); Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 77, 557 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 2001).
CONCLUSION
Based on a jurisprudential evaluation, we place our imprimatur and
  approbation upon the challenged indictments in regard to factual and legal
  sufficiency.Â  Because we hold that the specific date and time is not an element
  of the offenses of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and lewd
  act on a minor, the indictments in this case meet the test of â€œnotice
  documents.â€Â   
Accordingly, Tumblestonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  The jury acquitted Tumbleston of Indictment 2005-GS-10-807. 
 
[2]Â Â  The court directed a verdict of not guilty on Indictment
  2005-GS-10-809.
