title: Peake v. SCDMV
description: The direct and relevant issue involved in this appeal relates to the efficacy of section 56-5-2950 of the South Carolina Code of Laws.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John D.
      Peake, Appellant,
				v.
				South
      Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4313
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed November 27, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Timothy
  Clay Kulp, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Frank L. Valenta, Jr., of Blythewood, and Philip S. Porter, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â  Following a single
  car accident, John D. Peake (Peake) was arrested at the hospital for driving
  under the influence.Â  He refused to consent to a blood alcohol test and, as a
  result, the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (the Department)
  suspended his driverâ€™s license.Â  The suspension was affirmed at an
  administrative hearing and on appeal to the circuit court.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL /
  PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On February 5, 2005, Trooper J.T. Manley
  of the South Carolina Highway Patrol responded to a one car accident on I-26 in
  Charleston County.Â  He found Peake, the sole occupant of the wrecked car,
  buckled into the driverâ€™s seat.Â  As Trooper Manley spoke with Peake, he
  observed a strong smell of alcohol on Peakeâ€™s breath and noted his slurred
  speech.Â  EMS arrived shortly after Trooper Manley and transported Peake to Trident Regional Medical Center.Â  At the hospital, Trooper Manley placed Peake under arrest
  for driving under the influence.Â  Peake was read the Miranda rights and
  the Advisement of Implied Consent Rights.Â  Trooper Manley then requested Peake
  provide a blood sample believing Peakeâ€™s condition precluded a breath test.Â 
  Peake stated he understood his implied consent rights and refused to submit a
  blood sample.Â  Trooper Manley then issued Peake a Notice of Suspension which
  Peake refused to sign.
After
  receiving the Notice of Suspension, the Department suspended Peakeâ€™s license
  for ninety days.Â  Peake requested an administrative hearing pursuant to South
  Carolina Code section 56-5-2951(B)(2) (2006).Â  At the April 26, 2005, hearing, Trooper
  Manley appeared and testified on behalf of the Department.Â  He said he
  requested the blood sample because Peake was â€œnot able to give a breath sample
  due to his condition.â€ Â The record contains no explanation of Peakeâ€™s
  condition.Â  Peake did not appear though he was represented by counsel.Â  Peakeâ€™s
  counsel did not cross-examine Trooper Manley but asserted the mandatory
  suspension should be rescinded because the Department did not show medical
  personnel deemed Peake unable to give a breath sample in accordance with South
  Carolina Code section 56-5-2950(a).Â  The hearing officerâ€™s order sustained the
  suspension reasoning â€œ[Peake] verbally refused to give a blood or urine sample,
  as he was unable to give a breath sample.â€
Peake
  next appealed to the Court of Common Pleas in Charleston County where he complained
  Trooper Manleyâ€™s testimony did not justify the request for a blood sample.Â 
  Peake contended section 56-5-2950(a) requires law enforcement to seek the
  opinion of a medical professional that a person is incapable of providing a
  breath test.Â  The Department argued Peake was improperly shifting the burden of
  proof, the Departmentâ€™s actions were presumably correct pursuant to the
  Administrative Procedures Act, and the recordâ€™s substantial evidence supported
  the hearing officerâ€™s findings.Â   
In its
  written order, the circuit court interpreted section 56-5-2950(a) to â€œrequire
  the opinion of a medical professional if the subject is unable to give a breath
  sample for some reason outside those enumerated by the statute (e.g. injured
  mouth, unconscious, dead).â€Â  However, the judge then affirmed the suspension
  concluding â€œunder these facts, the officer was not required to seek the opinion
  of a medical professional as to Petitionerâ€™s ability to give a breath sample.â€Â 
 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. section 1-23-310, et seq.,
  (2005), establishes the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ rule as the standard for
  judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo,
    Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Summersell v. South Carolina
      Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 334 S.C. 357, 513 S.E.2d 619 (Ct. App. 1999), vacated
        in part on other grounds, 337 S.C. 19, 522 S.E.2d 144 (1999).Â  Section
  1-23-380(A)(5)Â  of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides:

	The court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm
  the decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The
  court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant
  have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences,
  conclusions, or decisions are:
	(a)  in violation of
  constitutional or statutory Â provisions;
	(b)  in excess of the
  statutory authority of the agency;
	(c)  made upon unlawful
  procedure; 
	(d)  affected by other
  error of law; 
	(e)  clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record;
  or
	(f)  arbitrary or
  capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted
  exercise of discretion.

The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and
  will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Kearse v.
    State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d
  892, 893 (1995); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles v. Nelson,
  364 S.C. 514, 519, 613 S.E.2d 544, 547 (Ct. App. 2005); Broughton v. South
    of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Â â€œA
  court cannot substitute its judgment for that of an agency as to the weight of
  the evidence on questions of fact unless the agencyâ€™s findings are clearly
  erroneous in view of the reliable probative and substantial evidence on the
  whole record.â€ Summersell, 334 S.C. at 363, 513 S.E.2d at 622; see also Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 466 S.E.2d 357
  (1996).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.â€Â  Nelson,
  364 S.C. at 519, 613 S.E.2d at 547;Â  see also Palmetto
    Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Public Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432,
  319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984) (declaring substantial evidence is something less
  than weight of evidence, and the possibility of drawing two inconsistent
  conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s
  finding from being supported by substantial evidence).Â  The circuit court
  essentially sits as an appellate court in reviewing an administrative agencyâ€™s
  final decision for alleged errors.Â  Kiawah Resort Assocs. v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 502, 458 S.E.2d 542 (1995); Nelson, 364 S.C.
  at 519, 613 S.E.2d at 547.
LAW /
  ANALYSIS
The issue in this case is whether the circuit court erred in
  finding Trooper Manley properly requested a blood test despite the absence of
  any opinion by licensed medical personnel that Peake was unable to provide a
  breath sample as required by the implied consent statute.Â  We find no
  substantial evidence establishing Trooper Manleyâ€™s compliance with the
  procedure mandated in section 56-5-2950(a).Â   
I.  The
  Implied Consent Statute
Being licensed to operate a motor vehicle on the public highways
  of this state is not a property right, but is merely a privilege subject to
  reasonable regulations under the police power in the interest of the public
  safety and welfare. Â State v. Collins, 253 S.C. 358, 170 S.E.2d 667 (1969); Summersell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 334 S.C. 357, 366,
  513 S.E.2d 619, 624 (Ct. App. 1999), vacated in part on other grounds,
  337 S.C. 19, 522 S.E.2d 144 (1999).Â  The privilege may be revoked or suspended
  for any cause relating to public safety, but it cannot be revoked arbitrarily
  or capriciously.Â  Taylor v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Motor, 368
  S.C. 33, 36, 627 S.E.2d 751, 753 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted; Sponar
    v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 361 S.C. 35, 39, 603 S.E.2d 412,
  415 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œAs part of this privilege, individuals operating motor
  vehicles implicitly consent to chemical tests of their breath, blood, or urine
  to determine whether they are under the influence of drugs or alcohol.â€Â  Taylor, 368 S.C. at 36-37, 627 S.E.2d at 753.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (2006).

	Section 56-5-2950(a) states in pertinent part:Â  
	
	A person who drives a motor vehicle in
  this State is considered to have given consent to chemical tests of his breath,
  blood, or urine for the purpose of determining the presence of alcohol or drugs
  or the combination of alcohol and drugs if arrested for an offense arising out
  of acts alleged to have been committed while the person was driving a motor
  vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of
  alcohol and drugs.Â  A breath test must be administered at the direction of a
  law enforcement officer who has arrested a person for driving a motor vehicle
  in this State while under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of
  alcohol and drugs. Â At the direction of the arresting officer, the
    person first must be offered a breath test to determine the personâ€™s alcohol
    concentration.Â  If the person is physically unable to provide an acceptable
    breath sample because he has an injured mouth, is unconscious or dead, or for
    any other reason considered acceptable by the licensed medical personnel, the
    arresting officer may request a blood sample to be taken. 
	 â€¦
	No test may be administered or samples obtained unless
  the person has been informed in writing that:
	(1)   he does not have to
  take the test or give the samples, but that his privilege to drive must be
  suspended or denied for at least ninety days if he refuses to submit to the
  tests and that his refusal may be used against him in court;
	(2)   his privilege to drive
  must be suspended for at least thirty days if he takes the tests or gives the
  samples and has an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one
  percent or more;
	(3)   he has the right to
  have a qualified person of his own choosing conduct additional independent
  tests at his expense;
	(4)   he has the right to
  request an administrative hearing within thirty days of the issuance of the
  notice of suspension; and
	(5)   if he does not request
  an administrative hearing or if his suspension is upheld at the administrative
  hearing, he must enroll in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program.

(emphasis added).
Under
  section 56-5-2951(A), the Department of Motor Vehicles must suspend the license
  of anyone who drives a motor vehicle and refuses to submit to a test provided
  for in section 56-5-2950 or who takes the test and registers an alcohol
  concentration of at least fifteen percent.Â  A person issued a notice of
  suspension may request an administrative hearing within thirty days.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(B)(2) (2006).
Section 56-5-2951(F) mandates â€œthe scope of the administrative
  hearing must be limited to whether the person:Â  (1) was lawfully arrested or
  detained; (2) was advised in writing of the rights enumerated in Section
  56-5-2950; [or] (3) refused to submit to a test pursuant to Section
  56-5-2950â€¦.â€Â  â€œThe gravamen of the administrative hearing is a determination of
  the efficacy and applicability of the implied consent law.Â  The query is:Â  did
  the person violate the implied consent law.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of
    Motor Vehicles v. Nelson, 364 S.C. 514, 525, 613 S.E.2d 544, 550 (Ct. App.
  2005).
II.  Rules
  of Statutory Construction
The
  primary rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the
  intent of legislature.Â  Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d
  372, 375 (2000); Shealy v. Doe, 370 S.C. 194, 199, 634 S.E.2d 45, 48 (Ct. App. 2006); City of Camden v. Brassel, 326 S.C. 556, 560, 486 S.E.2d 492, 494
  (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The first inquiry is whether the statuteâ€™s meaning is clear
  on its face.Â  Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d
  586, 588 (2002); Eagle Container Co., L.L.C. v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 622, 622 S.E.2d 733, 738 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  With any question
  regarding statutory construction and application, the court must always look to
  legislative intent as determined from the plain language of the statute.Â  State
    v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 700, 702 (2002); State v. Frey,
  362 S.C. 511, 516, 608 S.E.2d 874, 877 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Morgan,
  352 S.C. 359, 365-66, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002).Â   
When a
  statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite
  meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed, and this court has
  no right to impose another meaning.Â  Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. State, 372 S.C. 519, ___, 642 S.E.2d 751, 754 (2007); Vaughan v. Bernhardt, 345 S.C. 196, 198, 547 S.E.2d 869, 870 (2001).Â  â€œ[T]he
  words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without
  resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s
  operation.â€Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT&T Commcâ€™n of Southern
    States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004);Â  see also Miller v. Doe, 312 S.C. 444, 447, 441 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1994) (â€œIn
  determining the meaning of a statute, the terms used therein must be taken in
  their ordinary and popular meaning.â€).
The
  legislatureâ€™s intent should be derived primarily from the plain language of the
  statute.Â  Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 230,
  612 S.E.2d 719, 723 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Landis, 362 S.C.
  97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  The text of a statute is considered the
  best evidence of the legislative intent or will.Â  Jones, 364 S.C. at
  231, 612 S.E.2d at 724 (citing Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  344 S.C. 115, 122, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  The language must be
  read to harmonize with its subject matter and in accord with its general
  purpose.Â  Jones, 364 S.C. at 230, 612 S.E.2d at 723 (citing Hitachi Data Sys. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992)).Â  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statue is to determine
  the intent of the General Assembly. Â Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co.,
  350 S.C. 82, 87, 564 S.E.2d 358, 361 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the legislature
  has made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different
  judgment based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
If the language of an act creates doubt or uncertainty as to
  legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the
  borders of the act itself.Â  State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 367, 574
  S.E.2d 203, 207 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive
  practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose,
  design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  Collins Music Co., Inc. v. IGT, 365
  S.C. 544, 550, 619 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting TNS Mills, Inc. v.
    South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478
  (1998)).Â  Courts will reject statutory interpretations that lead to results so
  plainly absurd they could not have been intended by the legislature or that
  defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Jones, 364 S.C. at 232, 612
  S.E.2d at 724 (citing Unisun Ins. Co. v Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 368, 529
  S.E.2d 280, 283 (2000)); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc.,
  312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994)).Â  A court should not consider a
  particular clause in a statute in isolation, but should read it in conjunction
  with the purpose of the entire statute and the policy of the law.Â  Hinton v.
    South Carolina Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole, and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327,
  333, 592 S.E.2d 335, 338 (Ct. App. 2004); Doe v. Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 580,
  578 S.E.2d 733, 735-36 (Ct. App. 2003).
III.  Compliance
  with Section 56-5-2950(a)
The plain language of section 56-5-2950(a) permits an arresting
  officer to request a blood sample but unambiguously limits this to situations
  where a person is physically unable to provide a breath sample due to an
  injured mouth, unconsciousness or death, or for any other reason considered
  acceptable by the licensed medical personnel. Â Â In the case at bar, the
  Department has not asserted Peake had an injured mouth or was unconscious.Â 
  Therefore, the Department was required under the implied consent statute to
  show Peake was physically unable to give an acceptable breath sample for a
  reason found acceptable by licensed medical personnel.
In State
  v. Stacy, 315 S.C. 105, 431 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 1993) this court held the
  state complied with the licensed medical personnel determination requirement of
  section 56-5-2950(a). Stacy led police on a high speed chase that ended in a
  crash killing one person and injuring several others.Â  He appealed his
  convictions for two felony DUI counts and failure to stop for a police vehicle
  arguing his blood sample should have been suppressed because the State had not
  complied with section 56-5-2950(a).
Reading the statute as a whole, this court held â€œthe statute
  requires a licensed physician, licensed registered nurse, or other medical
  personnel trained to take blood samples â€¦ to determine whether an acceptable
  reason exists for finding that a person is unable to provide an acceptable
  breath sample.â€Â  Id. at 107, 431 S.E.2d at 641; (citing State v.
    Baker, 310 S.C. 510, 427 S.E.2d 670 (1993)).Â  The trained medical person
  who drew the blood testified Stacy was unable to provide a breath sample
  because he had not yet been treated and could not be transported to the law
  enforcement center. Â Because the evidence established the medical person
  considered this an acceptable reason, we found the statute permitted the taking
  of a blood sample without first offering a breath test.Â  Id.  
This
  court considered compliance with section 56-5-2950(a) and suppression of blood
  test results in City of Columbia v. Moore, 318 S.C. 292, 457 S.E.2d 346
  (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Moore was involved in a car accident, placed under arrest at
  the scene, and transported to the hospital in full spinal precautions.Â  The
  arresting officer testified he ordered the blood sample after being informed Moore could be in the hospital all night.Â  Finding the City failed to present any evidence
  of compliance with the procedure set forth in section 56-5-2950(a), this court
  noted â€œit is undisputed Moore did not have an injury to the mouth and was
  conscious at all times.Â  Therefore, the City was required to present evidence Moore was physically unable to give an acceptable breath sample for a reason found
  acceptable by licensed medical personnel.â€Â  Id. at 295, 457 S.E.2d at
  347.Â   
The City alleged the arresting officerâ€™s belief Moore would remain
  at the hospital a long time, coupled with the circumstances of his transport, provided
  a sufficient basis to conclude Moore was physically unable to give a breath
  sample.Â  This court answered â€œ[h]owever reasonable these conclusions may be
  under the circumstances, they are legally insufficient.â€Â  Id.Â  We
  explicated:

	To allow the arresting officer to make the
  determination that a person is physically unable to give an acceptable breath
  sample, absent an injured mouth, unconsciousness, or death, is a relaxation of
  the plain requirement of the statute, and would allow the substitution of the
  officerâ€™s judgment for that of licensed medical personnel.

Id. at 295, 457 S.E.2d at 348.Â  The City further averred Moore consented to the taking of a blood sample, but we elucidated: 
 

	[A driverâ€™s implied] consent is only to chemical tests under the
  procedure plainly set forth in the statute.Â  The penalty for refusal to submit
  to testing is the administrative loss of license for ninety (90) days. â€¦. In
  view of this statute, it would be pure legal fiction to infer Mooreâ€™s â€˜consentâ€™
  at the hospital was a voluntary relinquishment of his right to require compliance
  with the statute as written.

Id.
Although
  this court acknowledged the inability to leave a medical facility could provide a legally sufficient basis to conclude a person was physically
  incapable of providing a breath sample, we required â€œthe evidence must establish the reason a blood test was ordered in lieu of a breath sample is for
  a reason found acceptable by licensed medical personnel.â€Â  Id. (emphasis
  added).
In State
  v. Kimbrell, 326 S.C. 344, 481 S.E.2d 456 (Ct. App. 1997), this court again
  found noncompliance with section 56-5-2950.Â  Kimbrell was involved in a one car
  accident and taken to the hospital.Â  As she was leaving the hospital, the
  responding officer asked her to submit to a blood test.Â  The defendantâ€™s
  husband testified she had no injury to her mouth which prevented giving a
  breath sample.Â  The officer told the court she had a small amount of blood in
  her teeth.Â  Kimbrell consented to the blood test.Â  The officer did not offer or
  discuss a breath test with Kimbrell, ask about the condition of her mouth, or
  attempt to determine the extent of any injury.Â  Accordingly, the test results
  were suppressed because the record lacked sufficient evidence to support the
  officerâ€™s decision not to offer a breath test.Â  We inculcated:

	Unlike a breath test, the blood test is physically invasive.Â  By
  enacting the implied consent statute, the legislature clearly intended to
  protect against this invasion where it is used simply as a convenience to the
  arresting officer, absent the agreement of the accused.Â  There can be no valid
  agreement where the accused is not advised of his or her right to a breath test
  instead of a blood test.

Id., 326 S.C. at 348, 481 S.E.2d at 458-59; see also Taylor v. State, 368 S.C. 33, 627 S.E.2d 751 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted (explaining implied consent laws attempt to
  balance the interest of the State in maintaining safe highways with the
  interest of the individual in maintaining personal autonomy free from arbitrary
  or overbearing state action).Â  Relying heavily on the precedent of Moore, we determined â€œthe plain meaning of the statute requires the arresting
  officer to offer a breath test, absent a valid determination that the defendant
  is physically unable to give an acceptable breath sample.â€Â  Id. at 348,
  481 S.E.2d at 459.Â   
In State
  v. Long, 363 S.C. 360, 610 S.E.2d 809 (2005), our supreme court highlighted
  the requirements of section 56-5-2950 in order to distinguish section 56-5-2946.
  Â When the implied consent laws were rewritten by 1998 Act No. 434, section 7,
  section 56-5-2946, entitled â€œSubmission to testing for alcohol or drugs,â€ was
  created and applies only to persons believed to have committed Felony DUI.Â  The
  court found section 56-5-2946 removed the general requirements that an officer must
  first offer a breath test or get a medical opinion a breath test is not possible
  before ordering a blood test.Â  While hospitalized following a single car
  accident which killed a passenger, a blood sample was drawn from Long at the
  request of an officer.Â  Long objected to the introduction of the test results
  at trial because he had not been offered a breath test and no licensed medical
  personnel determined he was unable to provide a breath sample.Â  A study of the
  language of section 56-2-2946 led the court to conclude:

	[The first] two paragraphs essentially
  alter the procedural prerequisites which must be met under Â§ 56-5-2950 before
  an officer may order a blood test for a Felony DUI suspect.Â  Under Â§ 56-5-2946,
  the officer need no longer offer a breath test as the first option, nor must he
  obtain a medical opinion that such a test is not feasible before ordering a
  test or sample.

Id. at 363, 610 S.E.2d at 811.Â  See also State v.
  Cuevas, 365 S.C. 198, 616 S.E.2d 718 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding under section
  56-5-2950(a), unlike section 56-5-2946, arresting officer must first offer
  breath test).Â   
In the case sub judice, Peake was not suspected of
  felony DUI and the parties concede no breath test was first offered.Â  Apodictically,
  under section 56-5-2950(a), Trooper Manley could only have requested a blood
  sample if Peake was physically unable to provide a breath sample due to an
  injured mouth, unconsciousness, death, or for any other reason considered
  acceptable by the licensed medical personnel.Â  The record contains no
  substantial evidence supporting any of these exceptions. Indeed, the uncontested
  facts show the administrative hearing officer and the circuit court relied only
  on an unsubstantiated reason considered acceptable by Trooper Manley.  
The Department asserts â€œa reasonable mind could concludeâ€¦that
  [Peake] was â€˜unable to give a breath sample.â€™â€Â  In Moore, we established
  this conclusion, â€œhowever reasonable,â€ was legally insufficient because section
  56-5-2950(a) plainly establishes the determination of the licensed medical
  personnel is the standard.
The Department additionally contends that because a person cannot
  be transported from a medical facility to the locale of a DataMaster until
  released by licensed medical personnel, the statutory requirement of a medical
  opinion is necessarily satisfied â€œevery single time a motorist is taken to a
  medical facility for treatment and is not soon thereafter discharged.â€Â  The
  Department limits application of this notion to administrative hearings.Â  We are
  unaware of any statutory or jurisprudential basis for this proposition.Â 
  Although this court in Moore held the inability to leave a medical
  facility could form a legally sufficient basis for ordering a blood test, we
  expounded the record must show this determination is based on the opinion of
  licensed medical personnel.Â   
Section 56-5-2950(a) clearly articulates the statutory structure
  for chemical testing to which drivers impliedly consent. The record is
  absolutely devoid of any evidence showing Trooper Manley met the statutory
  requirements before requesting a blood test, therefore we find the decisions of
  the administrative hearing officer and the circuit court are clearly erroneous. 
 
CONCLUSION
Although the administrative hearing officer correctly concluded
  Peake was lawfully arrested, advised of his section 56-5-2950 rights, and refused
  to submit to a test, no substantial evidence shows the Department honored these
  rights in accordance with statutory provisions.Â  Therefore, the findings of the
  administrative hearing officer and the circuit court judge are  
REVERSED.
SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: McGriff v. Worsley Companies
description: The accident and resulting injuries suffered by a convenience store clerk arose out of and in the course of employment, entitling him to workers' compensation benefits.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jamar William
      McGriff, Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Worsley
      Companies, Inc. d/b/a Scotchman Stores, Employer, and Crum & Forrester
      Insurance, Inc., Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4314
Heard October 11, 2007 â€“ Filed November 27,
  2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stephen L. Brown, Wallace G. Holland, and Russell G. Hines, all
  of Charleston, for Appellants.
				Anthony E. Forsberg and Mark A. Mason, both of Mt. Pleasant for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.: Â Worsley Companies, Inc. appeals the circuit court order affirming
  the order of the appellate panel of the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission finding
  Jamar W. McGriffâ€™s injury compensable.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On
  September 5, 2001, McGriff applied for a job with Worsley Companies, doing
  business as Scotchman Stores, at store #98 on the corner of Remount Road and North Rhett Avenue in Charleston.Â  In the interim between the submission of his application
  and his eventual hiring at Scotchman, McGriff met David W. Chennault, a
  neighbor of McGriffâ€™s friend.Â  At the time of their acquaintance, both McGriff
  and Chennault were seeking employment and went â€œjob huntingâ€ together by
  submitting applications to various stores located on Remount Road.Â  On December
  19, 2001, Chennault submitted an application at store #98.Â  After submitting
  his application to Scotchman, Chennault was hired as a salesman for Country Fed
  Meats in Hanahan, South Carolina.Â  Subsequently, Chennault assisted McGriff in
  securing employment with the same company.Â  However, according to Chennaultâ€™s
  testimony, McGriff worked at Country Fed Meats for only a short time.Â   
I.  McGriffâ€™s
  Employment and Related Responsibilities
In early
  February 2002, McGriff accepted a position at store #98 as a third-shift sales
  clerk. Â According to the Scotchman
  Standard Duty List, third-shift clerks are required to complete numerous duties
  outside the physical confines of the store.Â  In particular, McGriff was
  expected to excel in his efforts to maintain the cleanliness of the outside
  premises as part of Scotchmanâ€™s â€œPride Rideâ€ program.Â  In addition,
  Scotchmanâ€™s â€œNew Beginning Training Manualâ€ required sales clerks to â€œ[a]lways
  keep applications on the [sales counter] and offer them to people you feel
  would be beneficial to Scotchman Stores.â€  
II.  McGriffâ€™s
  Accident
On
  February 9, 2002, at around 5:00 a.m., Chennault stopped his company truck at
  the intersection in front of the store, and saw McGriff outside cleaning the
  parking lot.[1]Â 
  Having recently worked at Country Fed Meats, McGriff apparently noticed the
  company truck stopped at the intersection and recognized Chennault as the
  driver.Â  Given the â€œnon-existentâ€ traffic at the time, McGriff crossed the
  storeâ€™s parking lot and entered the intersection to speak with Chennault.Â  McGriff
  stood at Chennaultâ€™s truck window approximately 12 to 15 feet from the curb of
  the Scotchman parking lot.  
According
  to Chennault, McGriff entered the intersection to inform Chennault that he had been
  hired by Scotchman.Â  Chennault asked McGriff whether McGriff would follow up on
  Chennaultâ€™s application.Â  In response, McGriff indicated he would speak with
  the store manager on Chennaultâ€™s behalf. Â As he turned to go back to the store,
  McGriff was struck by an oncoming car.Â   
III.  The Appellate
  Panel and Circuit Court Findings 
Before
  the single commissioner, the parties stipulated to a bifurcation of the claim
  so that compensability alone was the subject of the initial hearing. The single
  commissioner found McGriff had sustained a compensable injury as his actions
  were not a substantial deviation from his employment and because he was acting
  in the interest of his employer when he left the storeâ€™s premises.Â   

	The appellate
  panel affirmed the decision, stating:Â  
	
		Claimant
  had not abandoned his job.Â  He was not violating any company policy . . . .Â  There
  was no written prohibition against the Claimant leaving the store to clean the
  parking lot.Â  Further, there was the affirmative written expectation that the
  Claimant would assist his employer in finding applicants he felt would be
  beneficial to the company.Â  
	

The circuit
  court affirmed the appellate panelâ€™s order that found â€œboth the reason the
  claimant was outside and the reason he stepped into the intersection were
  specifically authorized and expected by his employer; even if the location was
  not.â€Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Generally,
  a reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the appellate panel unless
  the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an
  error of law.Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury
    Fund, 365 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œSubstantial
  evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached
  to justify its action.â€Â  Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C.
  469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â   
The
  question of whether an accident arises out of and is in the course and scope of
  employment is largely a question of fact.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg County Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Where facts are disputed, the findings
  of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349
  S.C. 451, 454-55, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, where the facts are undisputed, the question of whether an
  accident is compensable under workersâ€™ compensation law is a question of law.Â  Grant
    v. Grant Textiles,
  372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 872 (2007).Â  While the appellate courts are
  required to be deferential to the appellate panel regarding questions of fact,
  such deference does not prevent the courts from overturning the Panelâ€™s
  decision when it is legally incorrect.Â  Id. at 202, 641 S.E.2d at 872.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Injury Arising out
  of Employment 
Scotchman
  argues the appellate panel and circuit court erred in finding McGriffâ€™s injury
  compensable, because McGriffâ€™s injury did not arise out of his employment or
  occur during the course and scope of his employment.Â  We disagree.
In
  order to be entitled to compensation for an injury under the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, a claimant must show he suffered an â€œinjury by
  accident arising out of and in the course of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  42-1-160 (Supp. 2006).Â  However, â€œ[t]he two parts of the phrase â€˜arising out of
  and in the course of employmentâ€™ are not synonymous.â€ Â Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 49, 508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998).
  Rather, â€œ[b]oth parts must exist simultaneously before any court will allow
  recovery.â€ Â Id. Â According to this court in Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone
    Container Corp., 355 S.C. 154, 161, 584 S.E.2d 390, 394 (Ct. App. 2003) (internal
  citations omitted):

	The
  term â€œarising out ofâ€ refers to the origin of the cause of the accident. An
  accidental injury is considered to arise out of oneâ€™s employment when there is
  a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to
  be performed and the resulting injury. An injury occurs within the course of
  employment when it occurs within the period of employment, at a place where the
  employee reasonably may be in the performance of his duties, and while
  fulfilling those duties or engaged in something incidental thereto. 
	

While
  an injury must both â€œarise out ofâ€ and occur â€œin the course ofâ€ employment to
  recover for the injury, â€œ[t]here are circumstances when injuries arising out of
  acts outside the scope of an employeeâ€™s regular duties may be compensable. Â These
  circumstances have been applied to: Â (1) acts benefiting co-employees; (2) acts
  benefiting customers or strangers; (3) acts benefiting the claimant; and (4)
  acts benefiting the employer privately.â€Â  Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372
  S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007).Â  Furthermore, an act outside an employeeâ€™s regular
  duties that is undertaken in good faith to advance
  the employerâ€™s interest, whether or not the employeeâ€™s own assigned work is
  thereby furthered, is within the course of employment.Â  Id. at 202, 641 S.E.2d at 872.Â  
 
Thus,
  in determining whether an accident arose out of and in the course of
  employment, each case must be decided with reference to its own attendant
  circumstances.Â  Lanford v. Clinton Cotton Mills, 204 S.C. 423, 425, 30
  S.E.2d 36, 38 (1944). Â Moreover, the general policy in South Carolina â€œis to
  construe the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act in favor of coverage rather than
  exclusion.â€Â  Baggot v. So. Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 5, 496 S.E.2d 852,
  854 (1998).  
In Grant v.
  Grant Textiles,
  372 S.C. 196, 198-99, 641 S.E.2d 869, 870 (2007), the
  claimant, vice-president of sales for a family-owned textile company, was traveling
  to a meeting with clients when he stopped to remove debris from along the
  highway near the entrance to the site of the meeting.Â  Claimant was struck by a
  passing vehicle, and the court found his injury compensable.Â  Id., 372
  S.C. at 198-200, 641 S.E.2d at 870-72. Â According to the court, â€œthe full
  commission [of the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission] erred by finding that the
  accident did not have a causal connection with [Grantâ€™s] employment.Â  The
  accident would not have happened but for [his] business trip . . . to meet his
  employerâ€™s customers.â€Â  Id. at 201-202, 641 S.E.2d at 872.
In
  the present case, the record contains ample
  evidence substantiating the causal connection between the conditions under
  which McGriffâ€™s work was required to be performed and his resulting injury. Â As evidenced by the record: Â (1) at the time McGriff entered the road to engage in conversation
  with Chennault, McGriff was allowed and expected to be outside; (2) McGriff was
  allowed and expected to solicit new employees; (3) McGriff was allowed and
  expected to communicate inquiries to the store manager regarding employee
  prospects; and (4) McGriff was acting in good faith in the interest of his
  employer when he entered the road to discuss employment with Chennault.Â  There
  is substantial evidence in the record
  to support the determination that but for his employment with Scotchman,
  McGriff would not have entered the highway. Â McGriff knew the store was
  understaffed and knew Chennault was desirous of employment there.Â Â Â  According
  to Chennaultâ€™s testimony, the only thing the two discussed during their brief
  conversation was employment at Scotchman store #98.Â  Because there is
  substantial evidence in the record to support the findings, we cannot conclude
  that the appellate panel or circuit court erred
  in finding McGriffâ€™s injury arose out of his employment.  
II.  Injury Occurring in
  the Course of Employment
Scotchman
  also contends the appellate panel and circuit court erred in finding McGriffâ€™s
  injury compensable because McGriffâ€™s departure from the storeâ€™s premises
  constitutes a substantial deviation outside the course of his employment.Â  We
  disagree.  
Generally,
  an employee need not be in the actual performance of the duties for which he
  was expressly employed in order for his injury to be in the course of employment.
  Â See Beam v. State Workmenâ€™s Compensation Fund, 261 S.C. 327, 332,
  200 S.E.2d 83, 86 (1973) (noting â€œ[i]t is sufficient if the employee is engaged
  in a pursuit or undertaking consistent with his contract of hire and which in
  some logical manner pertains to or is incidental to his employment.â€).Â  As our
  supreme court noted in Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 190, 528
  S.E.2d 435, 444 (2000), â€œ[s]ince South Carolina does not look to fault, [the
  employeeâ€™s violation of a rule of conduct] must be a substantial deviation to
  remove his actions from the course of his employment, and disallow recovery of
  benefits.â€Â  Accordingly,  

	[W]hen
  an employee is in the performance of the duties of the employer, the fact that
  the injury was sustained while performing the duty in an unauthorized manner or
  in violation of instruction or rules of the employer does not make the injury
  one incurred outside the scope of employment. 

Id. at 190-191, 528 S.E.2d at 444 (citing Arthur Larson
  & Lex K. Larson, Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 37.02 (1999)).  
The
  record does not support Scotchmanâ€™s contention that McGriff abandoned his
  employment.Â  Although he technically left the boundaries of Scotchmanâ€™s
  premises, the fact that McGriff was outside of the store does not in and of
  itself violate any company rule.Â  Furthermore, according to Chennaultâ€™s testimony, McGriff was constantly glancing
  back toward the store during their conversation.Â  The situs of the conversation
  was approximately 12-15 feet from the Scotchman parking lot, and the
  conversation was as brief as the time of one cycle of the traffic signal at the
  intersection.Â  Thus, while McGriff may have deviated slightly from the general
  location of his job responsibilities, the record supports that such deviation
  was not so substantial as to remove him from the course and scope of his
  employment.Â  Accordingly, we
  hold neither the appellate panel nor the circuit court erred in finding McGriffâ€™s injury compensable.
III.  Chennaultâ€™s
  Testimony
Additionally,
  Scotchman argues the appellate panel erred in relying on a hand-written
  affidavit from Chennault that was previously excluded by the single commissioner
  as inadmissible hearsay.Â  We disagree.
The
  record shows Chennault gave a statement to investigating officers the day of
  McGriffâ€™s accident generally indicating that he and McGriff were talking about
  their new jobs at the time of the accident.Â  He apparently provided a
  hand-written affidavit approximately four days later. Â However, as the circuit
  court noted, â€œthere is no mention in the [Appellate Panelâ€™s] Decision and Order
  of reliance upon the excluded statement, only an acknowledgment that it
  existed.â€Â  Rather, the appellate panel only details the single commissionerâ€™s
  findings as to the first statement Chennault gave to police.Â  Because the
  record reflects no reference to the appellate panelâ€™s reliance upon Chennaultâ€™s
  second hand-written statement in making any determination of fact or conclusion
  of law, we hold the appellate panel did not err in relying on Chennaultâ€™s testimony.[2]
IV.  Witness Credibility 

Finally,
  Scotchman maintains the appellate panel erred in finding Chennault was a
  credible witness while two of their witnesses were not.Â  We disagree.
As
  noted by our supreme court in Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455,
  535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000), the final determination of witness credibility and
  the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â  Accordingly,
  the findings of the appellate panel are presumed correct and will be set aside
  only if unsupported by substantial evidence. Â Frame v. Resort Serv., Inc.,
  357 S.C. 520, 528, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (2004).Â  Furthermore, the possibility of
  drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the appellate
  panelâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v.
    Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999). 
 
Cross-examination
  of Chennault revealed he had exaggerated positive information on his employment
  application as well as lied about being fired from his previous job.Â  In
  addition, Chennault did not reveal any prior arrests on his application
  although he had bee previously arrested.Â  Nevertheless, the record shows
  Chennault and McGriff had a history of trying to assist one another with
  employment opportunities, and Chennaultâ€™s initial statement to police following
  the accident is consistent with his more detailed deposition testimony.Â 
 
Scotchmanâ€™s
  witness, Joseph Turner, observed the accident from a nearby Food Lion parking
  lot.Â  Turner indicated multiple times during his testimony that he was not â€œpay[ing]
  attentionâ€ to the specifics of the incident.Â  Leslie Flowers, the Scotchman store
  manager, gave testimony regarding the companyâ€™s policies and her own
  instructions to her employees about leaving the store that was arguably
  inconsistent.Â  Based on the record, we cannot conclude the appellate panel
  erred in making its findings on the credibility of these witnesses.Â   
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we hold neither the appellate panel nor the circuit court erred
  in finding McGriffâ€™s injury compensable under South Carolinaâ€™s Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act.Â  The decision of the appellate panel and the circuit court is
  accordingly
 AFFIRMED.
 SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  According to the testimony of Leslie
  Flowers, McGriff was notÂ  scheduled to work that shift but was called in due to
  the store being understaffed. Â 
[2]  Sligh v. Newberry Elec. Coop., Inc., 216 S.C. 401, 411, 58 S.E.2d
  675, 684 (1950), suggests that if an erroneously admitted document does not
  constitute the basis for an award, then it is harmless error.Â  If the appellate
  panelâ€™s mere acknowledgment of Chennaultâ€™s second statement was indeed
  erroneous, we find it was harmless error.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Frances Irene Todd, Appellant,
				v.
				Barbara C. Joyner, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Georgetown County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4315 
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  27, 2007
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled
  January 18, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Gene M. Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach,
  for Appellant.
				Linda Weeks Gangi, of Conway, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Frances Irene Todd appeals several
  evidentiary rulings of the trial court as well as the trial courtâ€™s denial of
  her motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS

On
  September 4, 2002, Todd and Barbara C. Joyner were involved in an automobile
  accident in Georgetown, South Carolina.Â  As a result of injuries sustained in
  the accident, Todd brought this action.Â  Joyner stipulated to her negligence in
  the case.[2]
On February 27, 2006, Joyner made Dr. Richard J. Friedman available for deposition as an expert in the field of orthopedic
  surgery.Â  Friedman was not available to testify live at the trial, and a
  redacted version of his deposition was read into evidence.Â  During the
  deposition, Todd questioned Friedman extensively about his private practice,
  the amount of his practice Friedman devoted to testifying as an expert witness,
  and the percentage of his income that came from testifying as an expert in an
  average year.Â  
Friedman could not recall specifics in his
  responses at the time of the deposition, and Todd subsequently subpoenaed
  records from State Farm Insurance Company regarding payments made to Friedman.Â 
  The records showed payments of between $50,000 and $60,000 to Friedman for the
  calendar years 2003 through 2005.Â  The trial court denied their admission into
  evidence because of the prejudicial impact of injecting insurance into the
  proceeding.Â  
Additionally, Todd objected to Friedmanâ€™s
  use of Toddâ€™s medical records as the foundation of his testimony as well as
  Friedmanâ€™s occasional reference to those records in his deposition.Â  The trial
  court overruled this objection.Â  Finally, Todd attempted to introduce, through
  cross-examination, a covenant not to execute entered into by Todd and State
  Farm.Â  The trial court denied the covenantâ€™s introduction.Â  The jury awarded
  Todd $37,191.11, the exact amount of her medical bills.Â  Todd made a timely
  motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â  The trial court denied the
  motion, and this appeal followed.

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Admission of
  Evidence of Expertâ€™s Connection to State Farm
Todd
  maintains the court improperly excluded evidence of the prior payments State Farm made to Friedman, which would be evidence of bias in favor of the
  defendant.[3]Â  We
  disagree.
The admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound
  discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an
  abuse of discretion.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467,
  611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is
  based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.
Historically, South Carolina restricted the admission
  into evidence of defendantsâ€™ insurance against potential liability in an action
  for damages before a jury.Â  Dunn v. Charleston Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 311 S.C. 43, 45, 426 S.E.2d 756, 757 (1993).Â  The reasoning behind this rule was
  to avoid prejudice in the verdict, which might result from the juryâ€™s knowledge
  that insurance, and not the defendant, would
  be responsible for paying any resulting award of damages.Â  Id. at 45,
  426 S.E.2d at 757-58.Â  However, â€œRule 411 modified this rule by providing that
  the admissibility of evidence of insurance depends upon the purpose for which
  such evidence is introduced.â€Â  Yoho v. Thompson, 345 S.C. 361, 365, 548
  S.E.2d 584, 585 (2001).Â  Rule 411 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence
  provides:

	Evidence that a person was or was not insured against
  liability is not admissible upon the issue whether the person acted negligently
  or otherwise wrongfully. Â This rule does not require the exclusion of evidence
  of insurance against liability when offered for another purpose, such as proof
  of agency, ownership, or control, or bias or prejudice of a witness.

Because Joyner stipulated to negligence, the records
  were not being offered to show that she was at fault.Â  Rather Todd sought to
  use them to discredit the defense expertâ€™s testimony. 
In Yoho
  v. Thompson, 345 S.C. 361, 365-66,
  548 S.E.2d 584, 586 (2001) the court explained if Rule 411 does not require the
  exclusion of the insurance evidence, and we find in this case it does not, the
  court must then consider whether the probative value of the evidence
  substantially outweighs its prejudicial effect and any potential confusion for
  the jury under Rule 403.Â  In order to accomplish this analysis, South Carolina has adopted the â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ test to determine whether an
  expertâ€™s connection to a defendantâ€™s insurer is sufficiently probative to
  outweigh the prejudice to the defendant resulting from the juryâ€™s knowledge
  that the defendant carries liability insurance.Â  Id. at 366, 548 S.E.2d
  at 586 (citing Bonser v. Shainholtz, 3 P.3d 422 (Colo. 2000); Mills
    v. Grotheer, 957 P.2d 540 (Okla. 1998)).Â  The substantial connection test
  has been adopted by a majority of the jurisdictions that have addressed this
  issue and is based upon the degree of connection between the expert and the
  insurance company.Â  Id.Â  
The court in Yoho did not articulate a defined
  test, but instead described the characteristics present in the case that led it
  to the conclusion a substantial connection existed, and ultimately that the
  evidence of bias should come in.Â  These characteristics included:Â  (1) the
  expert maintained an employment relationship with insurance companies; (2) the
  expert consulted for the insurance company in question in other cases and gave
  lectures to its agents and adjusters; (3) ten to twenty percent of the expertâ€™s
  practice consisted of reviewing records for insurance companies; and (4) the
  expertâ€™s yearly salary was based in part on his insurance consulting work.Â  Id.Â  Further, the Yoho court specifically found the expert â€œwas not merely
  being paid an expertâ€™s fee in this matter.â€Â  Id. 
The
  trial court distinguished Yoho from this case in several important
  aspects.Â  First, the court found it significant the expert in Yoho was
  present for live testimony during the trial.Â  This allowed the expert to be
  confronted about his connection to the insurance industry, instead of merely
  submitting an itemized list of payments into evidence.Â  As described above,
  Friedman was not available for cross-examination at trial.Â  Friedman could have
  been cross-examined with the records at his deposition, but Todd had not
  acquired the records at that point in time.Â  We also note Friedmanâ€™s bias was
  presented for the juryâ€™s consideration as his deposition testimony was read
  into the record.Â  This recitation included the extensive cross-examination by
  Todd bringing out the issue of potential bias.Â  As a result, the actual record
  of payments became less probative.
Next,
  the circuit court did not feel Friedmanâ€™s relationship with State Farm rose to
  the level described in Yoho because the only available evidence of his
  connection to State Farm was an itemized list of payments totaling between
  fifty and sixty thousand dollars over the course of three years.Â  The court
  found significant that no witnesses, including the two State Farm employees
  Todd called, could explain why these payments to Friedman were made.Â  The
  combination of these factors led the circuit court to conclude â€œthe prejudicial
  effect of injecting this insurance information into this case greatly outweighs
  the probative value because . . . thereâ€™s no opportunity to really do anything
  probative with this information; and itâ€™s really open to great latitude for
  abuse.â€Â  We find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in so holding.
II.  Covenant
  Not to Execute
Todd
  next contends the circuit court erred in refusing to admit into evidence the
  covenant between Todd and State Farm.Â  We disagree.
Todd relies upon the lone South Carolina decision
  addressing the admissibility of a covenant not to execute, Poston v. Barnes,
  294 S.C. 261, 363 S.E.2d 888 (1987).Â  In Poston, the plaintiff was
  injured when another driver struck a school van in which the plaintiff was a
  passenger.Â  The plaintiff, driver defendant, and the defendantâ€™s insurance
  company entered into a covenant not to execute.Â  Id. at 263, 363 S.E.2d
  at 889.Â  This covenant limited the defendant driverâ€™s liability for damages,
  while requiring her to remain a co-defendant, along with the school district,
  outwardly still subject to joint and several liability.Â  Id. at 265, 363
  S.E.2d at 890.Â  The court found the covenant was a facade, and the failure to
  disclose it to the jury tainted the judicial process.Â  Id.Â  

	[T]he jury was denied
  information to which it was entitled as to the sources of remuneration
  available to the plaintiff and by whom such remuneration would be paid.Â  The
  fact that the agreement was not disclosed to the jury in this instance facilitates
  inequity and injustice in the judicial process. . . .Â  Under the circumstances
  of this case, the agreement should have been allowed into evidence to insure
  that an equitable verdict was reached.Â  Id.

We find this case readily distinguishable from Poston.Â 
  Todd and Joyner were both insured by State Farm.Â  Todd entered into a covenant
  not to execute whereby she agreed not to execute against Joynerâ€™s personal
  assets and to take her recovery from Joynerâ€™s $25,000 liability policy, which
  was tendered, and Toddâ€™s own underinsured coverage.Â  So, at trial, Todd was
  essentially proceeding against her own insurance company.Â  Since naming the
  insurer is impermissible in this type of action, Joyner was the sole remaining
  party who could serve as the named defendant.Â  The primary circumstance that
  compelled the admission of the covenant into evidence in Poston, i.e.,
  the possibility of jury confusion due to multiple parties defendant, is simply
  not present here.
Toddâ€™s
  position is based in part upon her contention that during the opening
  statement, Joynerâ€™s counsel alluded to Joynerâ€™s responsibility to pay the
  entire amount of the damages award.Â  We find this contention is misplaced and
  taken out of context, as the crux of Joynerâ€™s opening statement did not focus
  on Joynerâ€™s personal responsibility for the damages.Â  Rather, Joyner questioned
  the reasonableness of the medical costs Todd claimed were necessitated by the
  automobile accident.Â  Because we find no evidence of an abuse of discretion
  amounting to an error in law in the record, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s
  decision to exclude the covenant.
III.  New
  Trial Nisi Additur
Todd next asserts the circuit court erred in not
  granting additur to the juryâ€™s damages award, which only reimbursed Todd
  for her medical expenses.Â  We disagree.
A trial court may grant a new trial nisi additur whenever it finds the amount of the verdict to be merely inadequate.Â  Green
  v. Fritz, 356 S.C. 566, 570, 590 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 2003).Â 
  â€œWhile the granting of such a motion rests within the sound discretion of the
  trial court, substantial deference must be afforded to the juryâ€™s determination
  of damages.â€Â  Id.Â  To this end, the trial court must offer compelling
  reasons for invading the juryâ€™s province by granting a motion for additur.Â  Id.Â  An appellate court will only reverse if the trial court abused its discretion
  in deciding a motion for new trial nisi additur to the
  extent that an error of law results.Â  Id.Â  The denial of a motion for a
  new trial nisi additur is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and
  will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Oâ€™Neal v.
    Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993).Â  â€œThe consideration
  of a motion for a new trial nisi additur requires the court to
  consider the adequacy of the verdict in light of the evidence presented.â€Â  Waring v. Johnson,
  341 S.C. 248, 257, 533 S.E.2d 906, 911 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  A trial court does not
  abuse its discretion in denying a
  motion for new trial nisi additur where
  evidence in the record supports the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  See Steele v.
    Dillard, 327 S.C. 340, 345, 486 S.E.2d 278, 281 (Ct. App. 1997)
  (finding no abuse of discretion where the evidence in the record supports the
  amount of the jury award even though other evidence in the record indicated the
  jury could have awarded a larger verdict).
The jury awarded Todd $37,191.11, her exact medical
  costs.Â  In the jury instructions, the circuit court provided the jury with a
  thorough explanation of how it could determine a monetary value for the damages
  to which it believed Todd was entitled.Â  This included a full explanation of
  actual damages, including:Â  â€œpast and future medical charges related to the
  injury, pharmacy charges, related expenses, pain and suffering, loss of
  enjoyment of life, as well as mental anguish and impairment of health or
  physical condition.â€Â  We find evidence in the record to support the juryâ€™s
  verdict.Â  Joyner argued that all of Toddâ€™s claimed damages were not proximately
  caused by the accident and that all of the medical treatment was not reasonably
  necessary.Â  Joyner cited the relatively low impact of the collision along with
  Toddâ€™s apparently limited injury immediately following the accident in support
  of her position.Â  Because there was evidence in the record to support the
  juryâ€™s verdict, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Toddâ€™s motion
  for new trial nisi additur.Â  
IV.  Expertâ€™s Reliance on Medical Records During
  Deposition
Finally, Todd contends the circuit court erred in
  allowing an expert to read medical records to the jury during his testimony.Â 
  We disagree.
The admission or rejection of testimony is largely
  within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion, the exercise of which will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Pike v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000).Â  Evidence is
  relevant if it has any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of
  consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable
  than it would be without the evidence.Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  Relevant evidence may
  be excluded, however, if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the
  danger of unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  
Experts may testify regarding facts or data, not as
  substantive proof of the facts so stated, but rather as information upon which
  they have relied in reaching their professional opinions.Â  Gentry v.
    Watkins-Carolina Trucking Co., 249 S.C. 316, 324, 154 S.E.2d 112, 117
  (1967).Â  Rule 703, of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence provides:

	The facts or data in the particular case upon which an
  expert bases an opinion or inference may be those perceived by or made known to
  the expert at or before the hearing.Â  If of a type reasonably relied upon by
  experts in the particular field in forming opinions or inferences upon the
  subject, the facts or data need not be admissible in evidence.Â  

Even if an expertâ€™s testimony is admissible under Rule
  703, the determination of whether an expert may testify to the facts underlying
  an opinion must be analyzed under Rule 403. Â State v. Slocumb, 336 S.C.
  619, 627, 521 S.E.2d 507, 511 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Because any evidence of Toddâ€™s
  medical history would have a minuscule prejudicial effect, if any, as opposed
  to the high probative value it lends as the basis of Friedmanâ€™s opinion, we
  agree with the circuit courtâ€™s determination. Â 
Finding no error of law, we conclude the circuit court
  did not abuse its discretion in allowing Friedman to opine as to the evidence
  contained within Toddâ€™s medical records.

CONCLUSION

  Based on the foregoing, we hold the circuit court did not err in
  failing to: Â (1) allow evidence to prove the bias of Joynerâ€™s expert; (2) admit the covenant not to execute between Todd
  and State Farm; and (3) grant Toddâ€™s new
  trial nisi additur motion.Â  Further, the circuit court did not
  err in allowing Joynerâ€™s expert to testify as to the contents of Toddâ€™s medical
  records.Â  The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED.
SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1]  We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Although the terms liability and negligence
  appear to have been used somewhat interchangeably during the trial, it is clear
  that Joyner only stipulated to negligence as opposed to liability.Â  
[3]  This section addresses the arguments in
  Toddâ€™s brief labeled Arguments I and III.

title: Lynch v. Toys â€œRâ€ Us-Delaware
