text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Luba Lynch, Respondent/Appellant,
				v.
				Toys â€œRâ€ Us-Delaware,
      Inc., Appellant/Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4316
Heard March 7, 2007 â€“ Filed November 27,
  2007
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Joel Collins, Jr. and Christian Stegmaier, both of Columbia, for Appellant/Respondent.
				Brooks Roberts Fudenberg, of Charleston and Geoffrey H. Waggoner,
  of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In
  this cross appeal, Toys â€œRâ€
  Us and Luba Lynch appeal
  various issues arising from a jury verdict in favor of Lynch.  Toys â€œRâ€ Us
  argues the circuit court erred by: (1) granting a directed verdict to Lynch
  rather than to Toys â€œRâ€ Us on the false imprisonment cause of action; (2) 
  denying its directed verdict/judgment
  notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV)
  motion on the causes of action for malicious prosecution, slander, and outrage;
  (3) denying its motion for a new trial absolute based on juror misconduct and
  the thirteenth juror doctrine; and (4) denying its motion for a new trial nisi remittitur. Â Lynch argues the circuit court erred in requiring her to
  elect a remedy.Â Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
On February 1, 2003, Lynch brought her mother, Tatiana Kotova, to
  a Â Babies â€œRâ€ Us store in North Charleston.Â  Kotova, a Russian National, was
  vacationing in the United States and this was her first visit to the baby
  superstore.Â  While shopping, Lynch decided to go to the restroom and handed some
  baby cookies she had selected to Kotova, who put them in a black canvas tote
  bag.  
A customer witnessed Kotova placing the items in the bag and
  reported the incident to a store employee. The employee went to the aisle and
  saw Kotova position a box into her bag, move around some other items, pull out
  what appeared to be a childâ€™s coat from the bag, and then push the coat down on
  top of the items.Â  The employee called the store manager, Nrurka Galarraga, to
  inform her that a customer saw â€œan older ladyâ€ putting merchandise inside a bag.[1]Â   
The manager contacted the North Charleston Police Department and
  then approached Kotova. Â Noticing a piece of black garment covering some of the
  merchandise in the tote bag, the manager asked Kotova if she could search it.Â  Although
  Kotova did not speak English and could not understand the managerâ€™s request,
  she permitted a search of the bag, wherein the manager discovered the boxes of cookies.Â 
 
Lynch returned from the ladiesâ€™ restroom to find Kotova in this encounter
  with the manager.Â  The manager asked Lynch about the cookies in the tote bag, and
  Lynch responded that she and Kotova were â€œgoing to buy [them].â€Â  The manager
  then provided Lynch and Kotova a shopping basket, in which Lynch placed the cookies,
  and gave them permission to continue shopping.Â  Lynch and Kotova later arrived
  at the checkout counter and purchased the cookies plus three additional items,
  for a total of $10.10.  
Meanwhile, officers from the North Charleston Police Department had
  entered the store and were talking to the manager.Â  The officers approached
  Lynch and Kotova as they were leaving the store, requested that they open their
  bag, and asked the manager, â€œwhere can we talk?â€ The manager then escorted Lynch,
  Kotova, and the officers into a nearby office for investigation.Â  In the
  office, the manager told the officers that Lynch and Kotova had persisted in
  their efforts to conceal merchandise, even after being provided with a shopping
  basket.Â  At trial, however, the manager testified that after giving the women a
  shopping basket they merely continued shopping and did nothing illegal or
  suspicious.Â  Â The manager also told the officers that she had confronted Lynch
  and Kotova twice for concealing items.Â  At trial, however, she recounted
  only one confrontation.
After the officers spoke with the parties, they gave the manager
  three options: (1) to put Lynch and Kotova on trespass notice; (2) to sign an
  affidavit and pursue a warrant for shoplifting; or (3) to press charges and effectuate
  an immediate arrest.Â  The manager elected the third option. Â The officers handcuffed
  Lynch and Kotova, escorted them through the busy store to the police car parked
  in front of the store, and transported them to jail.Â   
When the women arrived at the jail, they were patted down,
  stripped of their belongings, and escorted to their cells.Â  Lynch and Kotova
  spent ten hours in jail before being transported in handcuffs and shackles to a
  bond hearing.Â  Two hours after the bond hearing, they were released.Â  Lynch
  claimed she and Kotova could not sleep that night, and the next morning, Lynch went
  to church to seek comfort from her priest.Â  Lynch also testified to
  experiencing nightmares since the arrest.Â   
Lynch brought four causes of action
  against Toys â€œRâ€ Us, alleging false imprisonment, malicious prosecution,
  slander, and outrage.[2]Â 
  The case was tried before a jury, and at the close of the evidence, both Lynch
  and Toys â€œRâ€ Us moved for directed verdicts.Â  The circuit court denied all of Toys
  â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motions, but granted Lynchâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on false
  imprisonment.Â  The circuit court submitted the remaining causes of action to
  the jury.Â  The jury returned verdicts in favor of Lynch on all causes of action,
  and awarded $50,000 in actual damages and $250,000 in punitive damages on each.
 
Toys
  â€œRâ€ Us filed post-trial motions for JNOV, new trial pursuant to the thirteenth
  juror doctrine, new trial absolute, new trial nisi remittitur,
  and new trial based on juror misconduct.Â  The circuit court denied these
  motions.Â  However, the circuit court required Lynch to elect one of the four
  awards as the basis for her recovery.Â  Lynch elected to recover based on her
  malicious prosecution cause of action, and thus received $50,000 in actual
  damages and $250,000 in punitive damages for a combined total of $300,000.Â  These
  cross-appeals followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.   Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s
  Appeal
A.  Directed
  Verdict on False Imprisonment
Toys â€œRâ€ Us contends the circuit court erred by granting a
  directed verdict to Lynch on her false imprisonment cause of action and by
  denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the same issue.Â  We believe
  the issue of false imprisonment was for the jury to decide.
When ruling on a directed verdict motion, the circuit court is
  required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C.
    State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  The appellate
  court must follow the same standard.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons,
    Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995).Â  â€œIf more than one
  reasonable inference can be drawn or if the inferences to be drawn from the
  evidence are in doubt, the case should be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Chaney v.
    Burgess, 246 S.C. 261, 266, 143 S.E.2d 521, 523 (1965).Â   
The essence of the tort of false imprisonment consists of
  depriving a person of his or her liberty without lawful justification.Â  Law
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 440, 629 S.E.2d 642, 651 (2006).Â  To
  establish false imprisonment under South Carolina law, the plaintiff must show
  that the defendant restrained the plaintiff; the restraint was intentional; and
  the restraint was unlawful.Â  Id.; see also Gist v. Berkeley County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 336 S.C. 611, 618, 521 S.E.2d 163, 167 (Ct. App.
  1999).Â   
Toys
  â€œRâ€ Us raises the Merchantâ€™s Defense in regard to its actions.Â  Section
  16-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (2003) protects merchants and their
  employees who restrain or delay customers suspected of shoplifting if the
  customer was delayed in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable time to permit
  such investigation, and reasonable cause existed to believe that the customer
  delayed had committed the crime of shoplifting.Â  As set out in the statute, â€œreasonable
  causeâ€ is synonymous with â€œprobable cause.â€Â  S.C. Code Â§ 16-13-140 (2003).Â Â  Probable cause is defined as a good faith
  belief that a person is guilty of a crime when this belief rests on such
  grounds as would induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious person, under the
  circumstances, to believe likewise.Â  Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C.
  62, 65, 389 S.E.2d 662, 663 (1990).Â  The determination of whether probable
  cause exists is ordinarily a jury question; however, it may be decided as a
  matter of law when the evidence yields but one conclusion.Â  Law, 368
  S.C. at 441, 629 S.E.2d at 651.
Lynch acknowledged at trial that the Merchantâ€™s Defense would
  apply to the initial confrontation between the manager and her.Â  However, once
  the manager investigated the situation and resolved it by providing the women
  with a shopping basket and allowing them to continue to shop, Lynch argues the
  store had no right to again detain her once the police arrived.Â  The circuit
  court judge agreed and found as a matter of law that Lynch was falsely
  imprisoned when she was restrained in the office.Â   
After a thorough review of the record, we find there is evidence
  from which the jury could have determined Toys â€œRâ€ Us continued to have
  probable cause to detain Lynch even after the initial confrontation.Â  According
  to the managerâ€™s testimony, Lynch and her mother continued to act â€œvery
  nervousâ€ and went to different areas of the store â€œkind of hiding between
  fixtures.â€Â  Â Â From this evidence, the
  jury could have found probable cause existed to restrain the women once the
  police arrived to determine whether additional merchandise had been concealed
  after the initial confrontation. Â On the other hand, it was also in the juryâ€™s province to find that
  Toys â€œRâ€ Us no longer had probable cause once the women were allowed to
  continue shopping and ultimately paid for their merchandise.Â  Accordingly, the
  determination of whether Lynch was falsely imprisoned should have been
  submitted to the jury.
B.  Directed Verdict/JNOV Motions on the Remaining
  Causes of Action
Toys â€œRâ€ Us next contends the
  circuit court erred by denying its
  directed verdict motions on the remaining causes of action or, alternatively, by
  denying its motions for JNOV.Â  In ruling
  on a motion for JNOV, as in ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the circuit court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can
  be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the
  motion.Â  McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626
  S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006).Â  The motion should be denied when either the evidence
  yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Id.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s denial of such motions can only be reversed when there is no evidence
  to support the ruling or when the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â  

1.  Malicious Prosecution
As
  to its directed verdict and JNOV motions on the malicious prosecution cause of
  action, Toys â€œRâ€ Us contends the circuit court should have found the store had
  probable cause as a matter of law to prosecute Lynch. Â We disagree.
In
  order to recover in an action for malicious prosecution, the plaintiff must
  show (1) the institution or continuation of original judicial proceedings,
  either civil or criminal; (2) by, or at the instance of, the defendant; (3)
  termination of such proceeding in the plaintiffâ€™s favor; (4) malice in
  instituting such proceedings; (5) lack of probable cause; and (6) resulting
  injury or damage.Â  Ruff v. Eckerds Drugs, Inc., 265 S.C. 563, 566, 220
  S.E.2d 649, 651 (1975).Â  An action for malicious prosecution fails if the
  plaintiff cannot prove each of the required elements by a preponderance of the
  evidence, including malice and lack of probable cause.Â  Law v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 435, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  
 
Probable
  cause, which is a defense to an action for malicious prosecution, has been
  defined as â€œthe existence of such facts or circumstances as would excite the
  belief of a reasonable mind, acting on facts within the knowledge of the
  prosecutor, that the person charged was guilty of the crime for which he was
  prosecuted.â€ Â Eckerds Drugs, 265 S.C. at 568, 220 S.E.2d at 652.Â  Thus,
  for probable cause, the facts must be regarded from the point of view of the prosecuting
  party; the question is not what the actual facts were, but what the prosecuting
  party honestly believed them to be.Â  Law, 368 S.C. at 436, 629 S.E.2d at
  649.Â  Although the question of whether probable cause exists is ordinarily a
  jury question, in an action for malicious prosecution, it may be decided as a
  matter of law when the evidence yields but one conclusion.Â  Id.
In
  this case, evidence was presented to support Lynchâ€™s claim that Toys â€œRâ€ Us
  lacked probable cause to believe she had committed shoplifting, and malice may
  be inferred from a lack of probable cause to institute the prosecution action. Id., 368 S.C. at 437, 629 S.E.2d at 649.Â  Further, there was evidence to show the
  charge was pursued by Toys â€œRâ€ Us, it was terminated in Lynchâ€™s favor, and
  Lynch suffered damages as a result.Â  Therefore, the circuit court properly
  submitted the issue of malicious prosecution to the jury.
2.  Slander/Defamation
Toys â€œRâ€ Us next contends
  the circuit court erred in denying its motions for directed verdict and JNOV on
  the slander cause of action.Â  Specifically, Toys â€œRâ€ Us argues the evidence
  reflected a reasonable inference that Lynch intended to deprive the store of
  merchandise; it was justified in calling the police; there was no testimony of
  publication to a third party; and the report of Lynchâ€™s activities to the officers
  was subject to a qualified privilege.Â  We disagree.  
Initially, we note
  that Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s assertion of a qualified privilege as a defense to
  defamation is not preserved for our review. Â Because qualified privilege
  was not raised to the circuit court, we refuse to consider it on appeal.Â  See, e.g., State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 134, 620 S.E.2d 737, 741
  (2005) (holding that for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must
  have been raised to and ruled upon by the circuit court).Â   
The
  elements of defamation include: (1) a false and defamatory statement concerning
  another; (2) an unprivileged publication to a third party; (3) fault on the
  part of the publisher; and (4) either actionability of the statement
  irrespective of special harm or the existence of special harm caused by the
  publication.Â  Holtzscheiter v. Thomson Newspapers, Inc., 332 S.C. 502,
  518, 506 S.E.2d 497, 506 (1998).Â  Although slander is generally a spoken
  defamation, the supreme court has established that a defamatory insinuation may
  not only be made by word, but also by actions or conduct.Â  Tyler v.
    Macks Stores of South Carolina, Inc., 275 S.C. 456, 458, 272 S.E.2d 633,
  634 (1980).  
Here, the record
  indicates that there was sufficient evidence from which a jury could have found
  that Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s words and conduct were defamatory.Â  Evidence supports a
  claim that: (1) the manager and employee distorted the facts of Lynchâ€™s actions
  in telling the officers that Lynch and Kotova continued to steal items after
  confronted; (2) as a result of these statements, and at the direction of the manager
  and employee, the officers handcuffed Lynch and Mother and escorted them out of
  the store; (3) the officers put Lynch and Kotova into the backseat of their marked
  patrol car, which was parked in front of the store; and (4) Lynch suffered
  damage to her reputation.[3]Â 
  Lynch testified that while handcuffed and walking out of the store, â€œeverybody
  was looking at us.â€ Â In addition, this conduct occurred at a time in which Toys
  â€œRâ€ Us admits the store was â€œvery busy.â€Â   
Because
  a jury could have found that Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s statements concerning Lynchâ€™s
  behavior and its insistence on an immediate handcuffed arrest was a
  communication to both the officers and customers in the store that Lynch committed
  shoplifting, a jury question existed as to whether Toys â€œRâ€ Us slandered Lynch.
 
3.  Outrage
Toys â€œRâ€ Us
  contends that the circuit court erred by finding, as a matter of law, that
  outrage existed in this case.Â  We agree.Â   
To
  establish an action for outrage, the plaintiff must show that: (1) the
  defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress or
  was certain or substantially certain that such distress would result from his
  or her conduct; (2) the conduct was so extreme and atrocious as to exceed all
  possible bounds of decency and must be regarded as outrageous and utterly intolerable
  in civilized society; (3) the actions of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s
  emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff
  was so severe that no reasonable person could be expected to endure it.Â  Strickland
    v. Madden, 323 S.C. 63, 68, 448 S.E.2d 581, 584 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Initially,
  the court determines whether the defendantâ€™s conduct may reasonably be regarded
  as so extreme and outrageous as to permit recovery, and only if reasonable
  persons might differ should the question be one for the jury.Â  Id.
Here, evidence indicates
  that Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s employees never specifically saw Lynch do anything illegal,
  that Lynch and her mother were arrested after having paid for the merchandise, and
  that the manager distorted the facts to the officers.Â  We find these facts fall
  short of conduct â€œso atrocious that it exceeds all possible bounds of decency,â€
  as contemplated by the outrage cause of action.Â  Cf. Shipman v. Glenn,
  314 S.C. 327, 329, 443 S.E.2d 921, 922 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding that
  supervisorâ€™s conduct in ridiculing speech of employee with cerebral palsy and
  threatening to fire her was not sufficiently outrageous to support claim
  of outrage).Â  Further, there is a lack of evidence indicating Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s
  actions were outrageous to the extent they might be regarded as utterly
  intolerable in a civilized society.Â  But cf. McSwain v. Shei,
  304 S.C. 25, 29, 402 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1991) (holding that jury could find
  outrageous and intolerable conduct of an employer who forced employee to
  perform exercises in public which exposed her inability to control her
  bladder).Â  Therefore, the circuit court erred in denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motions
  for directed verdict and JNOV on the outrage cause of action.
C.  New
  Trial Based on Juror Misconduct
Toys â€œRâ€ Us contends the
  circuit court erred by
  denying its motion for a new trial absolute based on juror misconduct. Â Toys
  â€œRâ€ Us specifically contends that because a member of the jury lacked complete
  candor while responding under oath to voir dire and engaged in out-of-court
  investigation, its motion for a new trial should have been granted. Â We disagree.
1.  Jurorâ€™s
  Conduct During Voir Dire
Toys
  â€œRâ€ Us contends that because a member of the jury did not reveal his alleged prior
  false arrest to the circuit court during voir dire the juror
  should have been disqualified from serving on the jury, and the court erred in
  denying its motion for a new trial absolute based on this juror misconduct.Â  We
  disagree.
The
  granting of a new trial based on a jurorâ€™s failure to honestly respond to the
  courtâ€™s voir dire remains within the sound discretion of the
  circuit court.Â  Long v. Norris & Assocs., Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 568,
  538 S.E.2d 5, 9 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The appellate court will not reverse a
  circuit courtâ€™s decision to deny a new trial absolute motion absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  Id.Â  Further, when allegations arise concerning a jurorâ€™s
  failure to reveal information in response to voir dire questions,
  courts look to whether the concealment was intentional and consider the nature
  of the information concealed.Â  State v. Guillebeaux, 362 S.C. 270, 274,
  607 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A new trial is warranted if the court
  finds that the juror intentionally concealed the information and the concealed
  information would have supported a challenge for cause or would have been a
  material factor in the use of the partyâ€™s peremptory challenges.Â  Id.Â  However, a determination that a juror did not intentionally conceal the
  information ends the courtâ€™s inquiry.Â  Id.
In
  addition, as a policy matter, this court has refused to allow testimonies of
  jurors to impeach verdicts.Â  Barsh v. Chrysler Corp., 262 S.C. 129, 134,
  203 S.E.2d 107, 109 (1974).Â  Thus, upon an inquiry into the validity of a
  verdict, a juror may not testify as to any matter or statement occurring during
  the course of the juryâ€™s deliberations or to the effect of anything upon any
  other jurorâ€™s mind as influencing the juror to assent or dissent from the
  verdict.Â  State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 109, 610 S.E.2d 859, 867 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  A juror may only testify on the question of extraneous prejudicial
  information was improperly brought to the juryâ€™s attention or whether any
  outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror.Â  Id.Â  
 
Here,
  the circuit court directed a verdict in favor of Lynch on the false
  imprisonment cause of action, and there is no evidence that the jurorâ€™s silence
  regarding his alleged false arrest would have affected the juryâ€™s deliberation
  on the remaining issues.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence the juror
  intentionally concealed his history of false arrest or that the jurorâ€™s
  revelation had any influence on the other jurorsâ€™ decisions.Â  Accordingly, we
  find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion by denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s
  motion for a new trial absolute based on juror misconduct.  
2.  Out-of-Court Investigation
Toys â€œRâ€ Us also
  contends that because the same member of the jury went to Lynchâ€™s place of
  employment during a lunch break and thereafter reported to the remaining jurors
  that â€œLynch must be trustworthy to work in a store that sells such expensive
  items,â€ the jurorâ€™s out-of-court investigation was extrajudicial and
  prejudicial to the verdict.Â  We disagree.  
The
  determination of whether any person has a coercive effect on a jury for any
  reason is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Parker
    v. Evening Post Pub. Co., 317 S.C. 236, 247, 452 S.E.2d 640, 647 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The test is whether there is reason to believe outside influences affected
  the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Id.Â  In such a determination, the court will look
  to relevant factors such as: (1) the number of jurors exposed; (2) the weight
  of the evidence properly before the jury; and (3) the likelihood that curative
  measures were effective in reducing the prejudice.Â  State v. Covington, 343 S.C. 157, 164, 539 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
 
To
  constitute reversible error, the casual viewing of a public place must have
  been calculated to influence, and most likely must have influenced, the
  verdict.Â  75B Am. Jur. 2d Trial Â§ 1550 (2006).Â  However,
  even purposeful, unauthorized views of the premises made by a juror, in which
  the juror did nothing more than look at or examine the premises, is not
  automatically prejudicial.Â  Id.
Here,
  Toys â€œRâ€ Us again relied on the juror affidavits, which suggested that during a
  lunch break, one of the jurors visited Lynchâ€™s place of employment and reported
  to the remaining jurors that based on the upscale nature of the establishment, Lynch
  must be trustworthy.Â  There was no evidence that this influenced the verdict.Â  Moreover,
  evidence had already been presented informing the jury that Lynchâ€™s place of
  employment was an upscale retail establishment.Â  Thus, the jurorâ€™s visit to the
  store did not provide the jury with any information that was not already before
  it.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the circuit courtâ€™s denial
  of Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motion for a
  new trial absolute based on juror misconduct.Â   
D.  Thirteenth
  Juror Doctrine
Toys â€œRâ€ Us contends that because Lynch failed to prove the
  elements necessary to recover under all four causes of actions for false
  imprisonment, slander, malicious prosecution, and outrage, the juryâ€™s verdict
  was not supported by evidence, and the circuit court erred by denying its
  motion for a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  We disagree. 
 
South
  Carolinaâ€™s thirteenth juror doctrine
  allows the circuit court to grant a new trial absolute when the court finds the
  evidence does not justify the verdict.Â  Trivelas v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  357 S.C. 545, 551, 593 S.E.2d 504, 507 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The appellate court
  will not disturb a circuit courtâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon
  the facts unless its decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence or the
  conclusion reached was controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â   
As explained previously, we find sufficient evidence existed
  to support submission of the false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and
  slander causes of action to the jury.Â  We have also addressed the circuit
  courtâ€™s failure to direct a verdict on outrage above.Â  Thus, we find the
  circuit court did not err in denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motion for a new trial
  absolute based on the thirteenth juror doctrine.  
E.  New
  Trial and Juryâ€™s Excessive Award
Toys â€œRâ€ Us argues the circuit court erred by denying its motions
  for a new trial absolute or nisi remittitur based on the juryâ€™s
  excessive award of $50,000 in actual damages and $250,000 in punitive damages
  for each cause of action.Â  Toys â€œRâ€ Us specifically contends that because there
  was no testimony of Lynchâ€™s actual damages, and the reasonable conduct of its
  employees preclude any award of punitive damages, it was error for the court to
  deny its motions for a new trial absolute or nisi remittitur.Â  We
  disagree.  
The
  grant or denial of a new trial motion rests within the discretion of the circuit
  court, and its decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless its findings are
  wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by
  an error of law.Â  Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 368
  S.C. 279, 320, 628 S.E.2d 496, 518 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The circuit court alone
  has the power to grant a new trial nisi when it finds the amount of the
  verdict to be merely inadequate or excessive.Â  Id.Â  If the amount of the
  verdict is grossly excessive or inadequate so as to be the result of passion,
  caprice, prejudice, or some other influence outside of the evidence, the
  circuit court must grant a new trial absolute.Â  Id.Â  When the denial of
  a motion for a new trial nisi is appealed, this court will reverse when
  the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive, requiring the granting of a new
  trial absolute.Â  However, compelling reasons must be given to justify invading
  the juryâ€™s province by granting a new trial. Â Id. at 320, 628 S.E.2d at
  518. Â 
Here,
  evidence demonstrates Lynch suffered damages for each specific cause of action.Â 
  Lynch testified that she was arrested without justification; she was handcuffed
  and escorted to a police car in full view of customers; and she was jailed for
  ten hours, the combination of which also injured her reputation and led to her
  humiliation, sleeplessness, and emotional pain.Â  We find this constitutes
  evidence of actual damages.
Further, in South Carolina, â€œpunitive damages are allowed in
  the interest of society in the nature of punishment and as a warning and
  example to deter the wrongdoer and others from committing like offenses in the
  future.â€Â  Laird v. Nationwide Ins. Co., 243 S.C. 388, 396, 134 S.E.2d 
206, 210 (1964).  They serve â€œas a vindication of private rights when it is 
proved that such have been wantonly, willfully or maliciously violated.â€ Harris v. Burnside,
  261 S.C. 190, 196, 199 S.E.2d 65, 68 (1973).Â   
Evidence
  was presented to show that Toys â€œRâ€ Us wantonly, willfully, and maliciously fabricated
  and distorted the facts of Lynchâ€™s actions to the officers and rejected the officersâ€™
  alternatives to the immediate arrest of Lynch and her mother, all without ever
  observing any illegal action by Lynch.Â  Such evidence was sufficient for the jury
  to award punitive damages.[4]
For
  the foregoing reasons, and because Toys â€œRâ€ Us has not provided any compelling
  reasons to justify invading the juryâ€™s province by granting a new trial, we
  find the circuit court did not err in denying its motions for a new trial absolute or nisi remittitur based on the juryâ€™s award of damages.
II.  Lynchâ€™s Appeal: Election
  of Remedies 
Lynch
  contends the circuit court erred in requiring her to elect one of four causes
  of action for which the jury awarded damages, when those causes of action were
  based on different facts.Â  Because we have found the false imprisonment cause
  of action should have gone to the jury and the circuit court should have
  directed a verdict in favor of Toys â€œRâ€ Us on the outrage cause of action, we
  need only decide whether Lynch should have had to elect between the remaining
  malicious prosecution and slander verdicts.Â  We hold that she should not.
The
  doctrine of election of remedies requires a plaintiff to choose between different
  remedies allowed by law upon the same set of facts.Â  Jones v. Winn Dixie,
  318 S.C. 171, 175, 456 S.E.2d 429, 431 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Within this context,
  the facts refer to the defendantâ€™s wrongs or actions, so that when a plaintiff
  asserts only one primary wrong committed by the defendant, the plaintiff is
  entitled to only one recovery under the doctrine. Â Id.Â  Therefore, the doctrine
  has no application when two separate causes of action exist based on different facts.Â  Id.Â  Application of the doctrine should be confined to cases in which
  double compensation to the plaintiff is threatened.Â  Tomlinson, 367 S.C.
  at 470-471, 626 S.E.2d at 44-45.  
In Jones
  v. Winn-Dixie, 318 S.C. 171, 456 S.E.2d 429 (Ct. App. 1995), this court
  reversed the trial judgeâ€™s reformation of the juryâ€™s verdict to require an
  election of remedies between a false imprisonment verdict and assault and
  battery verdict.Â  In Winn-Dixie, Jones was suspected by a store manager
  of stealing shoe inserts from the store.Â  Id. at 173, 456 S.E.2d at 431.Â 
  The jury returned identical verdicts for each cause of action, including
  $25,000 in actual damages and $50,000 in punitive damages for each.Â  In finding
  election improperly applied, this court reasoned that the plaintiffâ€™s action
  for false imprisonment was not based upon the same elements as his action for
  assault and battery, and that the plaintiffâ€™s injuries occurred at different
  times and resulted from separate and distinct actions on Winn-Dixieâ€™s part.Â  Id.
As in Winn-Dixie,
  Lynchâ€™s causes of action were based upon different elements.Â  The essence of a
  claim for malicious prosecution is the lawful prosecution of an unwarranted
  criminal or civil proceeding against the plaintiff for malicious reasons,
  whereas slander consists of a false, defamatory statement communicated to a
  third party which results in injury to reputation.Â  See, e.g., Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 440, 629 S.E.2d 642, 651
  (2006); Williams v. Lancaster Co.
    School Dist., 369 S.C. 293, 302, 631 S.E.2d 286, 291-92 (Ct. App. 2006).
Also,
  Lynch suffered distinct injuries specific to each alleged wrong committed by
  Toys â€œRâ€ Us.Â  Lynch spent ten hours in jail, needed to hire an attorney, and
  suffered nightmares as a result of the malicious prosecution.Â  Lynch suffered
  injury to her reputation as a result of the slander.Â  The malicious
  prosecution injury began when Lynch was arrested at the insistence of Toys â€œRâ€
  Us, and the slander occurred when Lynch was escorted, while handcuffed, out of
  the store and into the police car in full view of the public. Thus, the
  circuit court erred by requiring Lynch to elect between her remedies for
  malicious prosecution and slander.Â   

  CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred by granting a directed verdict to
  Lynch on the false imprisonment cause of action.Â  The circuit court did not err by denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motions for
  directed verdict and JNOV on the malicious prosecution and slander causes of
  action.Â  Nor do we find the court erred in refusing to grant a new trial.Â  However,
  the circuit court erred by denying Toys â€œRâ€ Usâ€™s motion for directed verdict
  and JNOV on the outrage cause of action and in requiring Lynch to elect a
  remedy.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED
  IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
GOOLSBY and
  STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] The manager testified that the customer described the
  suspect as â€œan older lady;â€ however, the employee testified the customer
  reported that â€œsome ladiesâ€ were putting merchandise in a bag.
[2] Kotova returned to Russia after this incident and was
  not a party to this action.
[3] Slander involving the accusation that the plaintiff
  committed a crime of moral turpitude is actionable per se, which
  carries a presumption of general damages.Â  Holtzscheiter v. Thomson
    Newspapers, Inc., 332 S.C. 502, 511, 506 S.E.2d 497, 502 (1998).
[4] Toys â€œRâ€ Us does not challenge the award of punitive
  damages under Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 354 (1991).Â 
  Toys â€œRâ€ Us only argues its conduct did not rise to the level to support an
  award of punitive damages.

title: State v. Lynch
description: In this criminal case, we affirm the trial court's holding that an inmate was not entitled to be advised of his Miranda rights when he spoke to a t.v. reporter.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Jacob Lynch, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lee County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  4317
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  27, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, South Carolina Commission
  on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney
  General, of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson,Â  of Sumter, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.: In this criminal case, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s holding that an inmate was
  not entitled to be advised of his Miranda[1] rights when he spoke to a television reporter.  
FACTS
Prisoners rioted at the Lee Correctional Institution located in Bishopville,  South Carolina.Â  Correctional Officers Marcus Cotton (Cotton) and Kenneth
  Dozier (Dozier) were working in the Chesterfield Housing Unit at the time of
  the riot.Â  Prior to the incident, Cotton was providing meals to inmates located
  in the south side of the Chesterfield Unit, while Dozier provided meals to
  inmates located in the north side of the Chesterfield Unit.Â Â Â   
Cotton opened inmate Jacob Lynchâ€™s (Lynch) cell door to furnish Lynch
  a meal.Â  While the door of his cell was open, Lynch escaped.Â  Cotton ordered
  Lynch to return to his cell, but Lynch refused.Â  Rather than attempting to
  force Lynch back into his cell, Cotton continued with the feeding duties.[2]Â  Cotton then opened inmate Tyrone
  Singletaryâ€™s (Singletary) cell to provide him with a meal.Â  Singletary
  absconded from his cell and refused to return.Â   
Lynch and Singletary released other prisoners in the Chesterfield
  Unit and took Cotton hostage.Â  Cotton testified that during the struggle to
  capture him, Lynch and Singletary stabbed him with a shank.[3]Â   
Shortly after Cottonâ€™s capture, Dozier, who was delivering meals
  to the inmates on the north side, noticed Lynch and Singletary.Â  Lynch and
  Singletary attempted to capture Dozier, but Dozier managed to barricade himself
  in a room.Â  Lynch and Singletary sought to seize Dozier by breaking the door.Â 
  Lynch and Singletary threatened to kill Dozier and tried to stab Dozier.Â  However,
  neither apprehended Dozier.Â   
Cotton described Lynch as the leader of the riot.Â  During the
  subsequent hours of negotiations with law enforcement, Lynch controlled
  Cotton.Â Â  During the confrontation with law enforcement officials, Lynch would
  repeatedly come to the door of the Chesterfield Unit with Cotton handcuffed to
  him and demand access to the media.Â  Lynch and Singletary threatened to kill
  Cotton and Dozier if their demands were not met.Â   
Craig Melvin[4] (Melvin), along with other members of the media, covered the riot at Lee
  Correctional Institution.Â  The media requested an interview with the head of
  the Corrections Department, John Ozmint (Ozmint).Â  In response, Ozmint obtained
  the names and cell phone numbers of the members of the media who were present
  at the riot.Â  Ozmint called Melvin, and as a result of that call, Melvin entered
  the prison.Â   
Shortly before being interviewed by Melvin, Lynch released Cotton
  and surrendered.Â  Lynch was charged with two counts of taking a hostage,
  rioting, assaulting a correctional officer, carrying a weapon by an inmate, and
  inciting a riot.Â  The jury convicted Lynch on each count.Â  Consequently, Lynch
  was sentenced to life without the possibility of parole for the hostage counts,
  ten years for rioting, five years for assaulting a correctional officer, ten
  years for carrying a weapon by an inmate, and ten years for inciting a riot.Â  This
  appeal follows.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State
  v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  An appellate court
  is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  State v. Banda, 371 S.C. 245, 251, 639 S.E.2d 36, 39
  (2006).Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s determination of whether a defendant was
  deprived of his Miranda rights will be upheld unless unsupported by the
  record.Â  State v. Navy, 370 S.C. 398, 405, 635 S.E.2d 549, 553 (Ct. App.
  2006) (â€œAppellate review of whether a
  person is in custody for Miranda purposes is limited to a determination of whether the
  trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by the record.â€);Â  see State v.
    Easler, 322 S.C. 333, 342, 471 S.E.2d 745, 751 (Ct. App. 1996) (Appellate review on issue of whether defendant was in
  custody triggering Miranda warnings is limited to determination of
  whether the ruling by the trial court is supported by testimony.).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Lynch puts forth two arguments on appeal.Â  Shortly after Lynch
  released Cotton, Melvin interviewed Lynch.Â  During this interview, Lynch made
  several incriminating statements.Â  Lynch asked the trial court to suppress
  these statements, arguing Melvin became an agent of the State at the time of
  the interview.Â  Lynch contended statements made to Melvin were obtained through
  custodial interrogation initiated by law enforcement officials without Miranda warnings.Â  The trial court denied this motion.Â  
 
Lynch also objected to the introduction of videos obtained by the
  Department of Corrections.Â  The videos were taken during and subsequent to the
  riot.Â  They show, among other things, the negotiations between the inmates and
  law enforcement officials and the condition of the Chesterfield Unit after the
  riot.Â  Lynch argued the videos would inflame the passion of the jury and their
  prejudicial effect outweighed their probative value.Â  The trial court overruled
  this objection.Â  We address each argument in turn.  
A. The trial
  court correctly held that Miranda warnings were not required.
The
  Fifth Amendment provides, â€œNo person shall be . . . compelled in any criminal
  case to be a witness against himself . . . .â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. V.Â  Based on the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s protection
  against self-incrimination, the United States Supreme Court announced, â€œ[T]he prosecution may not use statements,
  whether exculpatory or inculpatory, stemming from custodial interrogation of
  the defendant unless it demonstrates the use of procedural safeguards . . . .â€Â  Miranda, 384 U.S. at 444.Â  Miranda rights[5] attach only if the suspect is subject to custodial
  interrogation.Â  State v. Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 303, 479 S.E.2d 838, 842
  (Ct. App. 1996).Â   
Custodial
  interrogation is â€œquestioning initiated by law enforcement officers after a
  person has been taken into custody or otherwise deprived of his freedom of
  action in any significant way.â€Â  Miranda, 384 U.S. at 444.Â 
  Specifically, interrogation is either express questioning or its functional
  equivalent.Â  Kennedy, 325 S.C. at 303, 479 S.E.2d at 842. Â The
  functional equivalent of an interrogation includes words or action on the part
  of the police, other than those that normally follow an arrest or custody, that
  the police should know are reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating
  response from the suspect.Â  State v. Binney, 362 S.C. 353, 359, 608
  S.E.2d 418, 421 (2005).
In the present
  case, Lynch was not subject to custodial interrogation when he spoke with
  Melvin.Â  Law enforcement officials at the site of the riot did not question
  Lynch.Â  Rather Lynch demanded, as a condition to release Cotton and as a condition
  of surrender, access to the media.Â  Melvin was provided to accommodate Lynchâ€™s
  demands.Â  During the interview, Melvin was acting as a private citizen, namely
  a reporter, and not as an agent of the State.Â  Melvinâ€™s testimony supports this
  conclusion.  

	
		
			Q:
			[A]s your duties as a news reporter,
  anchor, did you have an opportunity to come to Lee County . . . to cover a
  story at the Lee Correctional Institute?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes.
 
		
		
			Q:
			What was that story?
 
		
		
			. . . 
 
			 
		
		
			A:
			I was told . . . that there were some
  inmates who had taken some guards hostage and that they were requesting [a] member
  of the media to speak with.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And you became that member of the
  media?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes.
 
		
		
			. . . 
 
			 
		
		
			Q: 
			[W]hen the situation ended, when the
  crisis was over, did you interview a specific inmate named Jacob Lynch?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Yes.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And how did that occur?
 
		
		
			A:
			At the . . . end of this . . .
  situation . . . they brought Mr. Lynch over and I proceeded to . . . ask him
  some questions.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And you asked him about the . . .
  situation that took place inside [the Chesterfield Unit]?
 
		
		
			A: 
			I believe I asked him about that, you
  know, what happened in there and also asked him generally speaking, you know,
  his grievances.
		
	

(emphasis added).
Melvinâ€™s testimony
  demonstrates he was at Lee Correctional Instuttion covering the riot as a news
  reporter and not as an agent of the police.Â  Thus, Lynchâ€™s statements to Melvin
  were not the result of a custodial interrogation.Â   
Even if we assumed
  Melvin acted as an agent of the State at the time he interviewed Lynch, the Miranda warnings would be inapplicable.Â  The Miranda decision is meant to
  preserve the privilege against self-incrimination during interrogation of a
  suspect in a police dominated atmosphere.Â  Illinois v. Perkins,
  496 U.S. 292, 296 (1990).Â Â  The police dominated atmosphere generates
  â€œinherently compelling pressures which work to undermine the individualâ€™s will
  to resist and to compel him to speak where he would not otherwise do so
  freely.â€Â  Id. (internal quotations omitted). Â Â When an individual speaks
  to an undercover law enforcement official, Miranda warnings are not
  required.Â  Id.
Assuming Melvin
  acted as an agent of the police, Lynch would not have known this.Â  (â€œCoercion
  is determined from the perspective of the suspect.â€).Â  Id.Â  Rather,
  Lynch would have perceived Melvin as a reporter covering the prison riot.Â  During
  Lynchâ€™s interview, Melvinâ€™s questions were of the same nature that any
  reasonable reporter covering a riot would ask.Â  For example, Melvin asked Lynch
  what occurred inside the Chesterfield Unit, why the riot occurred, and what
  Lynchâ€™s grievances were.Â  If Melvin was operating as a government agent during
  the interview, he was doing so in an undercover capacity, thus making the Miranda warnings inapplicable.Â  Id. 
 
If we assumed Melvin
  acted as an agent of the State and Lynch was aware of this, the trial court did
  not err in refusing to suppress Lynchâ€™s statements.Â  The failure to suppress
  evidence for possible Miranda violations is harmless if the record
  contains sufficient evidence to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State
    v. Easler, 327 S.C. 121, 129, 489 S.E.2d 617, 621 (1997).Â  The record
  contains the testimony of numerous eyewitnesses that prove Lynchâ€™s guilt beyond
  a reasonable doubt.  
According to Cottonâ€™s
  testimony, Lynch stabbed and threatened to kill Cotton on at least three
  separate occasions.Â  Cotton described Lynch as the leader of the riot.Â  Although
  Cottonâ€™s testimony may be deemed as bias, other evidence supports Cottonâ€™s
  version.
Numerous correctional
  officers testified Lynch stabbed and threatened to kill Cotton. Â Sergeant Wanda
  Scarborough testified Lynch told her Cotton was being held as a hostage.Â  Lieutenant
  Robert Johnson testified Lynch threatened to kill Cotton with a homemade
  shank.Â  Sergeant Cedrick June testified he observed Lynch with a shank,
  witnessed Cotton handcuffed to Lynch, and saw Lynch stab Cotton in the shoulder
  twice.Â  Captain Arenda Thomas saw Cotton handcuffed to Lynch and witnessed Lynch
  stab Cotton.Â  Dozier testified Lynch threatened to kill Cotton.Â  Officer Yvonne
  Blandshaw testified she observed Cotton handcuffed to Lynch and saw Lynch stab
  Cotton twice.Â  Officer Cynthia York testified she saw Lynch stab Cotton twice.Â 
  Major John Ferraro, an expert in hostage negotiation, testified Lynch slapped,
  punched, and stabbed Cotton.Â  Major Ferraro also testified Lynch threatened to
  kill Cotton.Â  The overwhelming evidence of Lynchâ€™s guilt renders any possible Miranda violation harmless.
B. The trial court did not
  error by admitting the video tapes.
As noted above, Lynch objected to the introduction of
  videos obtained by the Department of Corrections.Â  These videos were taken
  during and subsequent to the riot.Â  They depict the state of the Chesterfield
  Unit after the riot, the negotiations between the inmates and law enforcement
  officials, and the condition of Lynchâ€™s cell.Â   
During the hours of negotiations, Cotton was held in Lynchâ€™s
  cell.Â  The videos portray a bloody rag in Lynchâ€™s cell. Â Lynch argued the
  videos would inflame the passion of the jury and their prejudicial effect out
  weighed their probative value.Â  The trial court overruled this objection.Â  
 
The admission of evidence
  is within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Pittman,
  373 S.C. 527, 577, 647 S.E.2d 144, 170 (2007).Â  To constitute an abuse of
  discretion, the conclusions of the trial judge must lack evidentiary support or
  be controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â   
Even
  if the trial court improperly admitted the videos, we find any error in their admission
  harmless because the videos were cumulative to other evidence which was
  properly admitted.Â  State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 372-73, 453 S.E.2d
  890, 891 (1995).Â  As explained above, numerous correctional officers testified
  Lynch stabbed and threatened to kill Cotton.Â  Thus, the trial court did not
  commit reversible error in admitting the videos.Â   
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[6]Â  
STILWELL
  and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[2] Cottonâ€™s explanation for why he continued with his
  duties instead of attempting to return Lynch to his cell is that correctional
  officers are trained not to engage in a combative situation by themselves.Â  Rather,
  officers are required to obtain assistance from other prison officers.Â   
[3] A shank is a homemade knife, most often time used by
  prisoners.Â   
[4] Melvin is a reporter with the Columbia television station WIS.Â  
 
[5] The well-known Miranda rights are that the accused must be informed of: the right to remain silent; any
  statement made may be used as evidence against him or her; and the right to the
  presence of an attorney.Â  State v. Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 303, 479
  S.E.2d 838, 842 (Ct. App. 1996). Â 
[6] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Swafford
description: This case discusses the third-party guilt evidentiary rule.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				David Swafford, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4318
Heard October 11, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  30, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Julie M. Thames, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M.
  Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.:Â  David Swafford appeals his convictions for felony driving under
  the influence resulting in death and leaving the scene of an accident resulting
  in death.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In
  January of 2003, Karen Reid died at the scene of a car accident.Â  Officers from
  the South Carolina Highway Patrol and the Pickens County Sheriffâ€™s Department
  found her van on the side of the road at the intersection of Highway 135 and Banks Road in Pickens County.Â  The van appeared to have rolled at least once.Â  Reid was
  thrown from and crushed under the van.Â  According to Officer Dale Marshall, the
  highway patrol received a call about the accident at approximately 3:35 p.m.
 
At the
  scene, officers received information that a truck had spun out in someoneâ€™s
  yard.Â  The officers located Swaffordâ€™s truck, which appeared to have been
  involved in the accident.Â  The officers found Swafford a short distance from
  the truck.Â  Swafford allegedly smelled of alcohol, acted intoxicated, and told
  them he had been alone in the truck.Â  According to breathalyzer test results,
  Swaffordâ€™s blood alcohol level was .14 percent.Â  At the police station,
  Swafford made a statement indicating he found out that day that his daughter
  had been raped, he drank for the first time in eight years, and all he
  remembers is waking up in the woods after the accident.  
Anthony Smith, a cable television contractor, testified he was
  working nearby at the time of the accident and witnessed the truck â€œsmoking
  like crazy on the front end.â€Â  Several hours later at the police station, Smith
  identified Swafford as the driver.Â  Charles Patterson testified he was at his
  home at the time of the accident.Â  He heard squealing tires and looked out his
  window to see the truck spinning through the neighborâ€™s yard.Â  He recognized
  Swafford, whom he knew as the driver.Â  Patterson testified he drove to the
  accident scene.Â  On the way, he saw his neighbor, Jerry Gillespie, walking in
  the area and picked him up.Â  Carol Balent witnessed the accident and identified
  the driver of the truck as having â€œlong stringy, like dirty blonde hair.â€
 
At
  trial, Swafford attempted to introduce third-party guilt evidence indicating
  Gillespie was driving the truck at the time of the accident.Â  Carol Johnson
  testified in camera that she is a school bus driver for Pickens County.Â  Johnson alleges she knows Swafford and saw him about 12:30 p.m. the day of the accident
  in the passenger side of the truck at a stop sign.Â  She described the driver as
  â€œa person . . . that had long dirty blonde hair.â€Â  She identified Gillespie in
  court as the driver.Â  Brian Bobo also testified in camera alleging Gillespie
  was his best friend and told him the evening of the accident that he had been
  driving Swaffordâ€™s truck and had been involved in a bad accident.Â  Gillespie
  allegedly drove the truck away from the scene and then fled on foot.Â  Robert
  Nealy, an investigator with the solicitorâ€™s office, testified in camera that a
  third witness, Greg Townsend, also claimed Gillespie admitted driving the truck
  at the time of the accident.Â  Townsend later told Nealy he was not sure who
  told him Gillespie was driving.Â  Townsend failed to appear in court the day of
  trial.  
Gillespie testified in camera, denying involvement in the
  accident.Â  He claimed he was at home when he heard a loud crash.Â  He
  rode with Patterson to the scene of the accident.Â  He denied telling Bobo or
  Townsend he had been driving the truck at the time of the accident.Â   
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œThe admission or
  exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose
  decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State
    v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Swafford
  argues the trial court erred in excluding Gillespieâ€™s proffered evidence of
  Gillespieâ€™s guilt.Â  We disagree.[1]Â  
 
South
  Carolina adopted the widely accepted rule regarding the admissibility of
  third-party guilt evidence in State v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 16 S.E.2d
  532 (1941).Â  The rule states:

	[E]vidence offered by accused as to the commission of
  the crime by another person must be limited to such facts as are inconsistent
  with his own guilt, and to such facts as raise a reasonable inference or
  presumption as to his own innocence; evidence which can have (no) other effect
  than to cast a bare suspicion upon another, or to raise a conjectural inference
  as to the commission of the crime by another, is not admissible . . . [B]efore
  such testimony can be received, there must be such proof of connection with it,
  such a train of facts or circumstances, as tends clearly to point out such
  other person as the guilty party. 

Gregory, 198 S.C. at 104-05, 16 S.E.2d
  at 534-35 (internal citations omitted).Â   
In State v. Gay[2]Â  and State v. Holmes,[3] the South Carolina Supreme
  Court altered the rule in Gregory by considering the strength of the
  prosecutionâ€™s case in determining whether to admit evidence of third-party
  guilt. See Holmes v. South Carolina, 126 S. Ct. 1727, 1733-34
  (2006) (discussing these South Carolina cases).Â  The United States Supreme
  Court vacated and remanded State v. Holmes and abrogated State v. Gay,
  explaining that weighing the strength of the prosecutionâ€™s case is arbitrary
  and does not rationally serve the end that the Gregory rule was designed
  to promote.Â  Id. In comparison, the Gregory rule requires the
  trial judge to consider the probative value or the potential adverse effects of
  admitting proffered third-party guilt evidence.Â  Id.Â   
This trial was
  conducted prior to the issuance of the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion in Holmes.Â  Swafford argues the trial judge improperly excluded the
  third-party guilt evidence and improperly relied on State v. Gay and State
    v. Holmes.Â  Swafford also argues the trial court erred in excluding the
  proffered testimony of hearsay statements made by Gillespie as they were
  exceptions to hearsay.Â  We disagree.
The trial judge
  mentioned State v. Gay and State v. Holmes while considering the
  proffered testimony.Â  He properly concluded, however, that â€œall these started
  with State v. Gregory . . . that imposed strict limitations on the
  admissibility of third-party guilt.â€Â  The trial judge compared the facts of
  this case to those in State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 514 S.E.2d 584
  (1999).Â  In Cooper, the defendant attempted to introduce testimony of a
  witness who allegedly overheard a third party telling a listener that she and
  two others murdered the victim.Â  Cooper, 334 S.C. at 547, 514 S.E.2d at
  588.Â  The alleged listener denied the statement.Â  Id.Â  The third party
  also denied the statement.Â  Id.Â  Relying on Gregory, the supreme
  court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of the evidence of third-party guilt.Â  Id. at 549-50, 514 S.E.2d at 589.Â  
 
After a careful
  review of the proffered testimony and the judgeâ€™s ruling, we find no
  unconstitutional reliance on State v. Gay or State v. Holmes.Â 
  Johnsonâ€™s testimony that she witnessed Swafford in the truck as a passenger
  several hours prior to the accident neither offers proof that he was a
  passenger at the time of the accident nor that Gillespie was the driver at
  either point in time.Â  At best, Johnsonâ€™s testimony raises the mere suspicion
  that Gillespie may have been driving an hour prior to the accident, but offers
  no reliable proof that he was driving at the time of the accident.Â  In like
  vein, Townsendâ€™s alleged statements to Nealy were so inconsistent they raised
  merely a bare suspicion of Gillespieâ€™s guilt.Â   
Finally, we find no
  error by the trial court in excluding Boboâ€™s testimony.Â  Bobo alleged Gillespie
  confessed to involvement in a bad accident in a telephone conversation with
  Bobo the night of this incident.Â  Bobo could produce no support for his bare
  assertion that he telephoned Gillespie the night of the accident.Â  He claimed
  he initiated the telephone call from the cellular telephone belonging to a
  â€œgirl named Jade.â€Â  Bobo knew neither her last name nor her telephone
  number.Â Â Â   
The trial judge in
  this case considered Cooper, reiterated the rule in Gregory, and
  considered the weakness of the proffered evidence rather than improperly
  focusing on the strength of the Stateâ€™s case.Â  We recognize this is a close
  case.Â  However, based on our limited standard of review, we find no reversible
  error by the trial judge in excluding the proffered evidence.[4]Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, Swaffordâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur

[1] Contrary to the Stateâ€™s argument, we find the issue
  preserved for appellate review.Â   
[2] 343 S.C. 543, 541 S.E.2d 541 (2001), abrogated
  by Holmes v. South Carolina, 126 S. Ct. 1727 (2006).
[3] 361 S.C. 333, 605 S.E.2d 19 (2004), vacated
  and remanded, Holmes v. South Carolina, 126 S. Ct. 1727 (2006).
[4] We decline to address the hearsay issue as we find the trial court
  ultimately excluded the evidence based solely upon whether it met Gregory.Â  See Litchfield Co. of S.C., Inc. v. Sur-Tech, Inc., 289 S.C. 247,
  251, 345 S.E.2d 765, 767 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding it unnecessary to determine
  whether trial judge erred in excluding evidence on one ground where trial judge
  did not err in excluding the evidence on another ground).Â

description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction of Anthony Woods for first-degree burglary and ABHAN.  On appeal, Woods claimed the trial court committed reversible error when it denied his motion to suppress Woodsâ€™ hair, blood, and saliva samples.  Woods claimed his Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable searches and seizures was violated because the State did not establish that the police submitted a sworn affidavit or made a statement under oath to support the order.  Consequently, the Court of Appeals found the trial judge failed to properly issue the search warrant as mandated by Section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) so the admission of the hair, blood, and saliva samples was improper.  However, because overwhelming evidence was presented to conclusively establish Woodsâ€™ guilt, the admission of the evidence was harmless error.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Anthony Woods, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4319
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  30, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
  Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  A jury found Anthony Woods (Woods) guilty of first-degree burglary
  and two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Woods
  argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to suppress hair, blood, and
  saliva samples as the products of an unlawful search and seizure and requests a
  new trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On June 4, 2003, Woods broke into the Taylor residence at approximately 11 p.m.Â  Linda Taylor (Linda) testified that on the night
  of the break-in, she was watching television in the den, which is near the back
  door. Â Her mother, Elizabeth Taylor, was getting ready for bed in the bathroom.
  Â Linda heard a noise outside, and when she looked through the blinds, she saw
  the motion sensor lights turn on and noticed Woods standing outside facing her
  through the window.Â  Linda testified Woods was â€œbathed in the flood lights,â€
  and she could â€œsee him very well.â€Â   
Woods punched his fist through the window pane of the door,
  causing his hand and arm to bleed.Â  Although Linda attempted to block the door
  with her body, Woods eventually pushed his way into the house and pushed Linda
  onto a chair in the den.Â  Woods then hit Linda in the face.Â  Linda found her
  mother lying on the floor after Woods escaped.Â  Thereafter, Linda noticed Woods
  had stolen the keys to the house and car, pocketbooks, tote bags, and a Bible.Â  
 
Shortly after the incident, Officer Surette was dispatched to the Taylor residence.Â  As Officer Surette approached the house, he noticed a suspicious person walking
  away from the Taylor residence. Â Although Officer Surette could not positively
  identify Woods at that time, Woods was apprehended in the same area after State
  Law Enforcement Division (SLED) brought in a bloodhound unit, which picked up Woodsâ€™
  trail.Â  Woods was eventually captured that night and positively identified.Â 
  Police took Woods to the hospital where he was treated for arm and hand injuries.Â  
 
On June 6, 2003, SLED Officer Creech approached Judge Cooper in
  chambers for a court order to obtain samples of Woodsâ€™ hair, saliva, and blood,
  which Judge Cooper granted.Â  While Judge Cooper found probable cause existed to
  issue the order, the State did not establish that Officer Creech submitted a
  sworn affidavit or made a statement under oath to support the order.Â   
During his trial, several police officers testified for the State,
  and Linda identified Woods as the man who broke into her residence.Â  After the
  trial, the jury convicted Woods of first-degree burglary and two counts of
  aggravated assault and battery.Â  The trial court sentenced Woods to life
  imprisonment for first-degree burglary and a concurrent ten years imprisonment
  on each count of aggravated assault and battery.Â  Woods appeals.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Further, we are bound
  by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id., 577 S.E.2d at 500-01.Â  Appellate review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure
  cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s
  finding.Â  State v. Banda, 371 S.C. 245, 251, 639 S.E.2d 36, 39 (2006); see
    also State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48-49, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006)
  (â€œThe trial judgeâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed
  due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed for clear error.â€).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Woods argues the trial
  court should have suppressed his hair, blood, and saliva samples as the products
  of an unlawful search and seizure.Â  He contends state officers failed to follow
  section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) in obtaining the court
  order.Â  We agree.Â 

Section
  17-13-140 provides:Â Â   

	A
  warrant issued hereunder shall be issued only upon affidavit sworn to before
  the . . . judge of a court of record establishing the grounds for the warrant.Â 
  If the . . . judicial officer abovementioned is satisfied that the grounds for
  the application exist or that there is probable cause to believe that they
  exist, he shall issue a warrant identifying the property and naming or
  describing the person or place to be searched.

Accordingly,
  a court order issued pursuant to this section, which stands in place of a
  search warrant, must be supported by a sworn oath or affirmation to be
  admissible at trial.Â  Baccus, 367 S.C. at 54-55, 625 S.E.2d at 223 (â€œFollowing
  these constitutional requirements, Â§ 17-13-140 requires a sworn affidavit for a
  search warrant [or a court order] to be issued.â€ (citing U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10)).Â  Furthermore, the affidavit must set forth
  particular facts and circumstances underlying the existence of probable cause
  to allow the magistrate to make an independent evaluation of the matter.Â  Franks
    v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154, 165 (1978).Â   
On
  June 6, 2003, Officer Creech approached Judge Cooper in chambers for an order
  to take samples of Woodsâ€™ hair, blood, and saliva.Â  Two other judges were
  present in chambers when Officer Creech requested the order.Â  Although Judge
  Cooper found probable cause to issue the order based on his conversation with
  Officer Creech, there was no affidavit from Officer Creech to support the court
  order, and Officer Creech failed to make a statement under oath as required by
  section 17-13-140.Â  The State conceded the order was defective on its face.Â  We
  find the court order failed to comply with statutory guidelines. Â Consequently,
  the hair, blood, and saliva samples should have been suppressed.Â   
Despite
  this error, we affirm Woodsâ€™ conviction in light of the overwhelming evidence
  of his guilt.Â  See, e.g., Baccus, 367 S.C. at 55, 625 S.E.2d at
  223 (â€œWhen guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no
  other rational conclusion could be reached, this Court will not set aside a
  conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting the result.â€).Â   
Here,
  the State presented evidence from several different sources.Â  Linda Taylor
  identified Woods as the assailant and testified in detail about the incident.Â 
  Woodsâ€™ fingerprints were found inside the door where he gained entry into the Taylor residence, and his hand injuries were consistent with having broken the glass
  window.Â  Officer Surette also testified he observed a suspicious person exiting
  the driveway of the Taylor residence who fled into the same area that officers secured
  after the break-in.Â  Bloodhounds then tracked Woods down within this secured
  area.Â  Finally, the police found several items stolen from the Taylorâ€™s residence along the trail where officers tracked Woods.Â  Therefore, we find the hair,
  blood, and saliva samples cumulative, and their admission is not grounds for
  reversal of Woodsâ€™ conviction.Â   
CONCLUSION
Although the trial court erred in denying Woodsâ€™ motion to suppress pursuant
  to section 17-13-140, such error was
  harmless in light of the overwhelming evidence establishing his guilt.Â 
  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  

STILWELL
  and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
